revision.text:
{{Multiple issues| {{cleanup|reason=inconsistent citation style, uses custom markup|date=May 2015}} {{globalize/US|date=May 2015}} }} In [[public administration]], '''administrative discretion''' refers to the flexible exercising of judgment and decision making allowed to public administrators.<ref>{{cite encyclopedia |title=Administrative Discretion |encyclopedia=Encyclopedia of public administration and public policy |year=2003 |page=35 |publisher=Dekker |location=New York |last=Rabin |first=J.}}</ref><ref name=Cann>{{cite journal|last1=Cann|first1=Steven|title=The Administrative State, the Exercise of Discretion, and the Constitution|journal=Public Administration Review|date=July 2007|volume=67|issue=4|pages=780–782|doi=10.1111/j.1540-6210.2007.00760.x}}</ref> Regulatory agencies have the power to exercise this type of discretion in their day-to-day activities, and there have been cases where regulatory agencies have abused this power. Administrative law can help these agencies get on the path of following regulations, serve the public, and in turn, a reflection of the public's values and beliefs.
There's a need for administrative discretion because the public’s interest could be at risk if several agencies were not following laws and regulations. Administrative discretion is important because without it, it could lead to arbitrary and unreasonable use of such discretion, which may lead to destruction of basic principles of administrative law.<ref name=Vaishnav>{{cite journal |last=Vaishnav |first=S. |last2=Marwaha |first2=K. |year=2015|title=Judiciary: A Ladder between Inevitable Administrative Discretion and Good Governance |journal=International Journal of Multidisciplinary Approach & Studies |volume=2 |issue=2 |pages=63–72}}</ref> Although this type of discretion isn't laid out in the job-description of a bureaucrat/public servant, it is necessary because citizens use these bureaucratic institutions every day; such as the D.M.V. , public schooling, and numerous others. [[street-level bureaucracy|Street-level bureaucrats]] have to deal with the provision of service as well as translating vaguely worded mandates into specific cohesive and comprehensive language to organize protocol.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Sowa|first1=Jessica E.|last2=Selden|first2=Sally Coleman|title=Administrative Discretion and Active Representation: An Expansion of the Theory of Representative Bureaucracy|journal=Public Administration Review|date=November 2003|volume=63|issue=6|pages=700–710|doi=10.1111/1540-6210.00333}}</ref>
Administrative discretion allows agencies to use professional expertise and judgment when making decisions or performing official duties, as opposed to only adhering to strict regulations or statuses. For example, a public official has administrative discretion when he or she has the freedom to make a choice among potential courses of action. The failure to exercise reasonable judgment or discretion is abuse of discretion.<ref>{{cite encyclopedia |title=Administrative Discretion |encyclopedia=West's Encyclopedia of American Law |year=2005 |accessdate=21 April 2015 |url=http://www.encyclopedia.com/doc/1G2-3437700153.html}}</ref>
"I think that in our system of government, where law ends, tyranny need not begin. Where law ends, discretion begins, and the exercise of discretion may mean either beneficence or tyranny, either justice or injustice, either reasonableness or arbitrariness."<ref>{{Cite book|title = Discretionary Justice: A preliminary inquiry |last = Davis|first = Kenneth C.|publisher = LSU Press|year = 1969|isbn = |location = |pages = }}</ref>—Kenneth Culp Davis
==History==
The idea of administrative discretion dates back as far as the time of widely known Greek philosopher [[Socrates]] in his quest to lay the foundation for philosophical ethics. Socrates determined a general ranking of "universal morals" in order to piece together certain criterion that could test what course of action to take in any immediate situation. He assigned value orders as well as certain "means to ends" that would determine alternatives for ethical philosophical generalization.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Leys|first1=Wayne A. R.|title=Ethics and Administrative Discretion|journal=Public Administration Review|date=Winter 1943 |volume=3|issue=1|pages=10|doi=10.2307/973098|jstor=973098}}</ref> In doing so, Socrates was creating the first type of basis for administrative discretion. [[File:Andrew Jackson 1873 Issue-2c.jpg|thumb|Andrew Jackson 1873 Postage Stamp—US Postal Service]] When [[Andrew Jackson]] took office in 1829, the country was going through radical changes—the scale of government grew extensively which caused the need for an increase in the administrative activity. Jackson brought the bureaucratization of administration.<ref name=Mashaw>{{cite journal|last1=Mashaw|first1=Jerry L.|title=Administration and "The Democracy": Administrative Law from Jackson to Lincoln, 1829-1861|journal=The Yale Law Journal|date=1 June 2008|volume=117|issue=8|pages=1568|doi=10.2307/20454693|jstor=20454693}}</ref> He appointed his close friends to office to work in administered processes. This was known as the "spoils system", in which was a system was in place where presidential administrations had the power of hiring or firing federal workers; this brought a constant change in demands and routines for personnel. Of his additions to the administrative discretion and of bureaucracy as we know it today, one in particular, the creation of [[History of United States patent law#Patent Act of 1836|The Patent Reform Act of 1836]] brought about the creation of new offices and adjudicatory administrative boards. Although, perhaps unknowingly, Jackson brought a new age to administrative discretion. Another president who has come in contact with administrative discretion is Madison. Known as Madison's Managers, drafted in 1787, some argue that early public administration literature had it right.<ref name=Cann/>
After Jackson, many presidents followed suit of his example—appointing members to administrative processes. In some cases, officials appointed by the presidents abused their powers in administration. There were attempts to control administrative discretion throughout the 19th century, but those attempts overall, failed. Political appointees believed they indeed were law themselves—Jesse Hoyt and his successor Samuel Swartwout for example, notoriously did not comply with the rule to return funds they had collected on behalf of the Federal Government.<ref name=Mashaw/> However, within the 20th century, substantial changes occurred that better formed the concept of administrative discretion as we know it today.
[[Franklin Roosevelt]]’s New Deal brought much needed relief to the public by implementing welfare programs in a dire time of crisis. There was a type of bureaucratic "sprawl": this era saw the creation of numerous agencies and boards. The birth of such a large bureaucracy, not only helped in aiding the public, but Roosevelt’s programs also answered important question of who would be part of the bureaucracy and govern future welfare programs. The New Deal emphasized the importance of administrative discretion in government and their processes by expanding the staff of the White House and creating new managerial techniques for the executive.<ref>{{Cite book |last=Morone |first=J. A. |year=1998 |title=The Democratic Wish: Popular participation and the limits of American government |publisher=Yale University Press}}</ref>
[[Administrative Procedure Act (United States)|The Administrative Procedure Act of 1946]] was created to govern the internal procedures of administrative agencies and how those agencies interact with the public. The act came about after the Attorney General appointed a committee to investigate the need for procedural reform.<ref>{{cite journal |last=Marble |first=R. D. |year=1948 |title=Federal Administrative Procedure Act of 1946 |journal=Mississippi Law Journal |volume=20 |page=62}}</ref> The notion of the time (not too far off-base of popular public notion today) was that various agencies were created by Congress over a long period of time in a piece-mail, haphazard manner. The view was that there was no uniformity in the chaotic bodies to administer anything. The 1946 act places policies on agencies’ rule-making, adjudications, and licensing behavior. The intention was to make sure that the public is protected and safe, with secured proper entitlements.
==Examples of administrative discretion in law== [[File:Compiègne Justice.jpg|thumb|Compiègne Justice]] ''[[Goldberg v. Kelly]]''—In this 1970 case, City officials were administrating and terminating public assistance benefits under the federally assisted program of Aid to Families with Dependent Children (AFDC) and/or under New York State’s Home Relief Program in New York City. The problem arose as residents receiving financial aid claimed that the New York City officials overseeing and administering these programs terminated their aid without notifying them or holding a hearing. Recipients alleged that this was unconstitutional on the Administration's part because it denying them due process of law guaranteed under the Due Process Clause in the Fourteenth Amendment (Case Briefs). In this case, Administrative Discretion resulted in individualized parameters of what was deemed necessary to convey a termination of aid, instead of a federal standard. The Holding of Chief Justice Warren Burger and the court sided with the appellants' view: a full hearing of evidence is required before a recipient can be denied/deprived of certain types of government benefits. In other words, a recipient must receive some sort of notice should their aid be changed/terminated; whether in writing or orally.
''[[Industrial Union Department v. American Petroleum Institute|Industrial Union Department v. American Petroleum Institute-]]-''In this 1980, [[Occupational Safety and Health Act (United States)|Under the Occupational Safety and Health Act of 1970]] (or OSHA), The Secretary of Labor was required to explicitly state exposure risks/limits at the lowest level of carcinogens that won't impair viability of the industries regulated. However, this failed to happen. The Secretary did not say or record anywhere that exposure to the substance benzene at 10 ppm (parts per million) would cause leukemia and exposure to 1 ppm would not (Oyez cases). The holding of the Supreme Court, under Justice Warren Burger, concluded that there was a statute for a requirement of significant risk, and the Secretary and agency had failed to uphold the statue of workers' health at risks.<ref name=Shapiro>{{cite journal |last=Shapiro |first=M. |title=Administrative Discretion: The Next Stage |journal=Yale Law Journal |volume=92 |page=1487 |year=1982 |url=https://scholarship.law.berkeley.edu/cgi/viewcontent.cgi?article=2706&context=facpubs}}</ref> In this case, Administrative Discretion under the Secretary of Labor had not understood the "extent feasible" .
''[[Citizens to Preserve Overton Park v. Volpe|Citizens To Preserve Overton Park, Inc. v Volpe]]--''In this 1971 case, in Memphis, Tennessee, a group of citizens claimed that The Secretary of Transportation made the decision to have construction of a highway where Overton Park was located and violated statutes enacted by the congress.<ref name=Shapiro/> The court holding under justice Burger upheld the "feasible and prudent" clause: wherein an alternative exists to circumvent building the proposed highway through the park. Furthermore, the Secretary's decision to use federal money for the highway did not comply with the Department of Transportation Act of 1966.
''[[IRS targeting controversy|The IRS Tea Party Controversy]]'': The IRS must exercise discretion in administering the tax law. The IRS oversees a vast system that affects nearly everyone. Since the law is complex and often difficult to interpret, the IRS must draw fine lines in order to properly interpret, apply, and enforce the law.<ref>{{cite journal |last=Kahng |first=L.|year=2013 |title=The IRS Teas Party Controversy and Administrative Discretion |journal= Cornell Law Review Online |url=http://cornelllawreview.org/files/2013/09/99CLRO411.pdf |volume=99 |pages=41–55}}</ref> The IRS claims it gave extra scrutiny to Tea Party-affiliated groups based solely on the name and goals of the groups. The IRS asked those groups invasive questions that were not normally asked of other groups: about their donor lists, affiliations and contacts with the media .<ref>{{cite web |last=Korte |first=G. |date=13 May 2013 |title=Q&A: The IRS-Tea Party scandal explained |accessdate=2015-04-13 |url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/news/politics/2013/05/13/irs-tea-party-scandal-explained/2156009/ |work=USA Today}}</ref>
Administrative Discretion in Criminal Law Enforcement''--'' When a government official of law enforcement uses their own sense of ethical discretion such as not to or to invoke in criminal process.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Goldstein|first1=Judith|title=International law and domestic institutions: reconciling North American "unfair" trade laws|journal=International Organization|date=22 May 2009|volume=50|issue=4|pages=541|doi=10.1017/s0020818300033506}}</ref> There are two major situational motivations of police discretion; whether police response is internally invoked or citizen initiated and whether it is a law enforcement of order maintenance situation. The two situational motivations combine to create four types of discretionary situations for law enforcement officials. The four different situations are proactive and reactive law enforcement and proactive and reactive order maintenance.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Reiss|first1=Albert J.|title=Consequences of Compliance and Deterrence Models of Law Enforcement for the Exercise of Police Discretion|journal=Law and Contemporary Problems|date=Autumn 1984|volume=47|issue=4|pages=83|doi=10.2307/1191688|jstor=1191688|url=https://scholarship.law.duke.edu/lcp/vol47/iss4/5}}</ref>
==Modern day administrative discretion== {{OR section|date=May 2015}} In today’s administrative discretion, some issues affect the way organizations function and the way the public feels towards administrations/agencies as a whole. In this way public administrators are seen as "moral agents"; they are given the task to exercise discretion, and reflect the society’s values. In theory, the public expects administrators to be the exemplary role models of society and follow laws and regulations. [[File:Shimer College dialogue transparency 2010.jpg|thumb|Shimer College dialogue transparency 2010 "We want dialogue and transparency." ]]In reality, some do not think the administrators play fair and the public feels distrusts towards them. In a poll done by Gallup.com, the public showed an increase in the mistrust in government. People were asked if corruption was widespread throughout the government. The results recorded from 2006 to 2013 rose significantly; from 56% to 79%.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Clifton|first1=Jon|title=Americans Less Satisfied With Freedom|url=http://news.gallup.com/poll/172019/americans-less-satisfied-freedom.aspx|publisher=Gallup|language=en-us}}</ref> The public may know little to nothing about the administration or their responsibilities, yet approval is very low. Some{{who|date=May 2015}} attribute this mistrust to a lack of transparency, where corruption can occur.<ref name=Vaishnav/> The lack of transparency can mean that an administration is not completely honest, secretly keeping hidden agendas: withholding information from public view. It can also simply mean that the administration does not attempt to make their information easy to access or understand for the public.
==References== {{reflist}}
==Further reading== *Adler, J.H. (2014). How much discretion does the executive branch have over immigration policy? The Washington Post. Retrieved from https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/volokh-conspiracy/wp/2014/12/01/how-much-discretion-does-the-executive-branch-have-over-immigration-policy/ *[[Mark Bovens|Bovens, M.]], & Zouridis, S. (2002). From Street-Level To System-Level Bureaucracies: How Information And Communication Technology Is Transforming Administrative Discretion And Constitutional Control. Public Administration Review, 62(2), 174-184.{{doi|10.1111/0033-3352.00168}} *Garofalo, C. (2008). With Deference to Woodrow Wilson. Public Integrity, 10(4), 345-354. *James, Malcolm David. "Cutting a Good Deal – UK Uncut, Goldman Sachs and the Challenge to Administrative Discretion." Journal of Applied Accounting Research 14.3 (2013): 248-67. Web. *Koch Jr., Charles H. (1986). Judicial Review of Administrative Discretion. William & Mary Law School Scholarship Repository. Retrieve from http://scholarship.law.wm.edu/cgi/viewcontent.cgi?article=1569&context=facpubs *Miller, Arthur S. "Administrative Discretion in the Award of Federal Contracts." Michigan Law Review 53.6 (1955): 781-812. JSTOR. Web. 10 Mar. 2015. *Miller, Cheryl M. "Review: Administrative Discretion and Public Policy Implementation." The American Political Science Review 80.4 (1986): 1354-355. JSTOR. Web. 10 Mar. 2015. *Pekelis, Alexander H. "ADMINISTRATIVE DISCRETION AND THE RULE OF LAW." Social Research 10.1 (1943): 22-37. JSTOR. Web. 10 Mar. 2015. *Rabin, R. (1976). Job Security and Due Process: Monitoring Administrative Discretion through a Reasons Requirement. The University of Chicago Law Review, 44(1), 60-93. *Rao, Ravitej. M. (1993). Control of Abuse of Administrative Discretion: Judicial Trends. Manupatra. Retrieved from https://web.archive.org/web/20160305174951/http://www.manupatra.co.in/newsline/articles/Upload/2F200227-E95A-408D-B1EA-77CFE9702C36.pdf *SHANE, P. M. (2013). The Rule of Law and the Inevitability of Discretion. Harvard Journal of Law & Public Policy, 36(1), 21-28. *Shapiro, S., Fisher, E., & Wagner, W. (2012). The Enlightenment of Administrative Law: Looking inside the Agency for Legitimacy. Wake Forest Law Review, 47(3), 463-502. Retrieved March 9, 2015, from Social Science Research Network. *Stein, J. (1960). POLICE DISCRETION NOT TO INVOKE THE CRIMINAL PROCESS: LOW-VISIBILITY DECISIONS IN THE ADMINISTRATION OF JUSTICE. The Yale Law Journal, 69(4), 543-544. Retrieved April 1, 201, from http://digitalcommons.law.yale.edu/cgi/viewcontent.cgi?article=3417&context=fss_papers *Stein, D. (2011, March 31). Retrieved from http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1111/j.1468-2230.1947.tb00052.x/pdf *Williams David, Sir David Q.C. (1994). Law and Administrative Discretion. [[Category:Public administration]]

{{about||the Danish artist|Arthur Nielsen (painter)|the ''Warehouse 13'' character|Arthur "Artie" Nielsen}} {{Infobox officeholder | birth_name = Arthur Charles Nielsen | birth_date = {{birth date|1897|9|5|mf=y}} | birth_place = [[Chicago]], [[Illinois]] | death_date = {{death date and age|1980|6|1|1897|9|5|mf=y}} | death_place = Chicago, Illinois }} '''Arthur Charles Nielsen Sr.''' (September 5, 1897{{spaced ndash}}June 1, 1980) was an American businessman, electrical engineer and market research analyst who founded the [[ACNielsen|ACNielsen company]], a market research company.
==Background== Arthur Charles Nielsen was born in [[Chicago]], [[Illinois]]. He was of [[Danish people|Danish]] descent. Nielsen was educated at University of Wisconsin (now [[University of Wisconsin–Madison]]), where he received a B.S., summa cum laude in 1918. He was a member of [[Tau Beta Pi]] (engineering honor society), the [[Sigma Phi|Sigma Phi Society]] and a captain of the [[Varsity team|varsity]] [[tennis]] team from 1916 to 1918. He subsequently served in U.S. Naval Reserve.
==Career== Nielsen worked as an electrical engineer for the Isko Company in Chicago from 1919 to 1920 and for the H. P. Gould Company in Chicago from 1920 to 1923. He founded the [[ACNielsen]] company in 1923, and in doing so advanced the new field of [[marketing research|market research]]. This involved: (1.) [[test market]]ing new products to determine their viability prior to costly [[mass marketing]] and production; and (2.) measuring product sales at a [[random sample]] of stores to determine [[market share]]. Careful [[statistical sampling]] was crucial to this process. The techniques developed by Nielsen were especially important for the efficient operation of a [[Market (economics)|market]] prior to the introduction of computerized [[digital network]]s that in the 1990s enabled continuous and comprehensive monitoring of sales by product retailers. Nielsen was also a pioneer in developing methods of measuring the audience of radio and [[television broadcasting]] programs, most notably the [[Nielsen ratings]].<ref>'' A.C. Nielsen. U.S. Media Market Researcher'' (The Museum of Broadcast Communications) [http://www.museum.tv/eotv/nielsenac.htm]</ref>
Nielsen inaugurated a National Radio Index for broadcasters and advertisers in 1942, followed by a television ratings service in 1950. By the time of his death, the company's revenue was US$398 million annually.<ref>"[http://www.time.com/time/magazine/article/0,9171,924209,00.html Milestones, Jun. 16, 1980]", ''Time'', June 16, 1980.</ref>
==Personal life== With his son Arthur Nielsen Jr. he won the U.S. Father and Son doubles tennis titles in 1946 and 1948. He was elected to the [[International Tennis Hall of Fame]] in 1971 for his contributions to the sport. The University of Wisconsin awarded him an honorary Doctor of Science (ScD) in 1974. Nielsen was appointed a Knight of the [[Order of the Dannebrog]], ''Ridder af Dannebrog'' (1961) by the government of [[Denmark]].<ref>''North American Medal Recipient Index'' (The Order of Dannebrog and other Royal Scandinavian medals by William P. Jones) {{cite web|url=http://www.danishmuseum.org/fhgc/resources/Danish-American_medal_index.pdf |title=Danish Maerican Medal|accessdate=2009-08-28 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110725215719/http://www.danishmuseum.org/fhgc/resources/Danish-American_medal_index.pdf |archivedate=2011-07-25 }}</ref>
Nielsen and his wife Gertrude (d.1998) donated the Nielsen Tennis Stadium to the University of Wisconsin–Madison.<ref>University of Wisconsin-Madison. [http://www.recsports.wisc.edu/nielsen.html Nielsen Tennis Stadium] retrieved 19 August 2011.</ref> In 1990, the A.C. Nielsen family made a donation to UW-Madison to create a full-time MBA program specializing in market research. It is the only full-time market research program in the United States. A small tennis center in [[Winnetka, Illinois]], is named after him.
==Professional recognition== *Annual Advertisement Awards Committee, 1936 *Chicago Federated Advertisements Club, 1941 *[[American Marketing Association]], 1951 and 1970 *Hall of Fame in Distribution in 1953 *International Advertisement Association, 1966
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== * [http://bus.wisc.edu/nielsencenter A.C. Nielsen Center for Marketing Research] * [https://web.archive.org/web/20100813143744/http://www.tennisfame.com/hall-of-famers/arthur-nielsen International Tennis Hall of Fame]
{{Authority control}}

revision.text:
[[File:Zak WestBank.jpg|thumb|250px|Bashar Masri with [[United States Trade and Development Agency|U.S. Trade and Development Agency]] Director [[Leocadia I. Zak]] and an architect at the [[Rawabi]] site.]] '''Bashar Masri''' (/{{lang-ar|بشار مصري}}/ February 4, 1961) is a [[Palestinian American]] entrepreneur and successful business man, he is the founder and [[Chairman|Chairman of the Board]] of Massar International, since its establishment in 1994. He is the founder and visionary behind the high-tech "[[Rawabi|Rawabi City]]", Palestine's first planned city, he is also the founder and currently the managing director of Bayti Real Estate Investment Company that built the city.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/research/stocks/private/person.asp?personId=111402495&privcapId=107355227|title=Executive Profile: Bashar Masri|last=|first=|date=|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref> He founded and manages the first Palestinian equity fund, a 90 million investment initiative known as "Siraj Fund".<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.globes.co.il/en/article-1000622030|title=Siraj Fund raises $60m for Palestinian high tech|last=|first=|date=|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref> He's on the list of the "Top Ten Richest People of Palestine in 2016" with net worth estimated at 1.5 Billion Dollars.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.richincomeways.com/luxury/top-ten-richest-people-of-palestine-in-2016/|title=Top Ten Richest People of Palestine In 2016|last=|first=|date=|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref>
== Early life == Masri was born in [[Nablus]], [[State of Palestine|Palestine]] and raised there.<ref>[http://www.americantaskforce.org/daily_news_article/2011/02/23/1298437200_20 Palestinian-American Entrepreneur Re-Envisions West Bank Development]</ref><ref>{{cite news |title=West Bank: Palestinians’ first planned city will offer modern space |url=http://features.csmonitor.com/globalnews/2009/11/04/west-bank-palestinians-first-planned-city-will-offer-modern-space/ |work=[[The Christian Science Monitor]] |date=4 November 2009 |accessdate=10 December 2009 }}</ref> After leaving Nablus, Masri continued his education first in Egypt then moved to the United States, [[Virginia]] where he Graduated from [[Virginia Polytechnic University]] with a B.S. in [[Chemical engineering|Chemical Engineering]] in 1983.<ref>{{cite news|title=The first (planned) Palestinian city |url=http://fr.jpost.com/servlet/Satellite?cid=1259243039024&pagename=JPost/JPArticle/ShowFull |work=[[The Jerusalem Post]] |date=30 November 2009 |accessdate=10 December 2009 }}{{dead link|date=October 2016 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.americantaskforce.org/daily_news_article/2009/11/03/1257224400_14|title=BUILDING IN THE WEST BANK: An Interview with Bashar Masri|last=|first=|date=|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref> He worked in a number of countries before he decided to return to Palestine and settle there in the mid-1994, among them the [[Saudi Arabia|Kingdom of Saudi Arabia]], the [[United States|United States of America]] and the [[United Kingdom]]. and with a background in [[management consulting]] and [[industrial management]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/research/stocks/private/person.asp?personId=111402495&privcapId=107355227|title=Executive Profile: Bashar Masri|last=|first=|date=|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref>
On a regional level, Masri has spearheaded large and economically significant investment projects, including [[affordable housing]] [[Community|communities]] in [[Morocco]], commercial and residential developments in [[Jordan]], and a residential real estate project in [[Egypt]]. Massar Company under Masri's management currently has multiple businesses in [[Morocco]], [[Jordan]], [[Egypt]] and [[Serbia]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.globes.co.il/en/article-1000622030|title=Siraj Fund raises $60m for Palestinian high tech|last=|first=|date=|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref>
Masri is the father of two daughters: Tamara Masri and Dina Masri.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.americantaskforce.org/daily_news_article/2009/11/03/1257224400_14|title=BUILDING IN THE WEST BANK: An Interview with Bashar Masri|last=|first=|date=|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref>
== Business in Palestine ==
=== Al-Ayyam Newspaper === After Masri came back from [[Washington, D.C.|Washington DC]] to [[Palestine (region)|Palestine]] in Mid-1990s to establish himself in his home country, he started by founding Palestinians daily newspaper "Al-Ayyam Newspaper (/Arabic: جريدة الأيام/)" and was its publisher. Al Ayyam is today the second largest newspaper in Palestine.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.ft.com/content/ac890172-2024-11e3-9a9a-00144feab7de|title=Peace dividends|last=|first=|date=|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref>
=== Massar International Ltd === In 1994, Masri founded and now is the Chairman of the board of Massar International,<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.massar.com/?TemplateId=info&PageId=2&MenuId=13&Lang=1|title=Chairman letter|last1=|first1=|date=17 February 2018|work=|accessdate=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|location=}}</ref> since the establishment of Massar, he has been one of the most prominent figures promoting private sector development and growth in Palestine.He has dedicated his life to establishing, investing, transforming, networking, training and building what is now a widely known group of businesses bridging Palestine to global technologies, knowledge, know-how and industry best practices. In the past decade, he has launched businesses in [[financial services]], [[real estate]], [[Media (communication)|media]] and [[communication]]s, retail businesses, [[agribusiness]] and [[information technology]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/research/stocks/private/snapshot.asp?privcapId=107354853|title=Company Overview of Massar International|last=|first=|date=|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref>
According to Massar International's website, these companies are either owned by Massar International or Massar International has invested in them:[http://www.massar.com]
==== The Real Estate sector ====
# Bayti Real Estate - Palestine # Bayti Investment - Morocco # Palestine Investment and Development - Palestine # Tamleek for Investment and Real Estate Development - Jordan # Al-Quds Holding - Palestine
==== Financial Services ====
# Sahem Trading and Investment - Palestine # Siraj Fund Management - Palestine # The National Bank (TNB) - Palestine # Palestine Mortgage and Housing Corporate (PMHS) - Palestine # The Palestinian Company for Rental and Leasing (Pallease) - Palestine # Al-Tadamon Al-Arabi Brokerage (TA-Invest) - Egypt # Energo Broker a.d. Beograd - Serbia
==== Information Technology Sector ====
# ASAL Technologies - Palestine # Call u Communication - Palestine # WebTeb - Palestine # Bader ICT Incubator - Palestine
==== Media and Communication ====
# Publicis Zoom - Palestine # High Definition Vision (HD Vision) - Palestine # Al-Ayyam Printing, Press, Publication & Distribution - Palestine
==== Agriculture ====
# Harvest Export - Palestine # Nakheel Palestine for Agriculture Investment - Palestine
==== Other Sectors ====
# Massar Consulting and Technical Services - Palestine # Alpha International for Research, Polling and Informatics - Palestine # Travel Masters - Jordan # Decorx for Wood Industrial - Palestine # Palestinian Logistics and Distribution Services (Wassel) - Palestine # Ziadah Architects and Engineers - Palestine # PalGaz for Gas Distribution and Services - Palestine # The Palestinian Company for Hospitality Services - Palestine
=== Rawabi City & Bayti Real Estate === Not only was Masri the visionary and founder of Rawabi City, he also oversees the construction and development of the city. Rawabi City is a [[High tech|high-tech]] [[Planned community|planned city]], the first of its kind in Palestine, and it was funded fully by the private sector, Rawabi is considered the largest private sector investment is Palestine's history, the construction of the city so far has cost 1.4 billion dollars. Rawabi is being constructed by Bayti Real Estate Investment Company that is jointly owned by [[Qatar]]i Diar Real Estate Investment Company and Massar International.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.rawabi.ps/bayti/about_bayti.php|title=About Bayti|last=|first=|date=|website=|access-date=}}</ref> With its more than 6,000 housing units built to serve families from multiple demographics, state-of-the-art infrastructure, and an emerging commercial hub, the city has already made a positive economic and social impact on Palestinians and it is constructed to provide housing for 25,000 person in its first stage and 40,000 people when it is done.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.rawabi.ps/press_show.php?id=6|title=PRESS RELEASE|last=|first=|date=|website=|access-date=}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://english.pnn.ps/2017/05/17/video-rawabi-city-opens-biggest-shopping-center-in-palestine/|title=Video: Rawabi city opens biggest shopping center in Palestine|last=|first=|date=|website=|access-date=}}</ref> Not only does the city provide affordable housing options it is also the second biggest generator of jobs, after the [[Palestinian government|Palestinian Government]], providing between 8,000 and 10,000 job opportunity a year for [[construction worker]]s,<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/monicawang/2016/07/06/one-mans-dream-city-rises-in-the-occupied-west-bank/#bd1b258732d0|title=One Man's Dream City Rises In The Occupied West Bank|last=|first=|date=|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref> in addition to thousands of job opportunities, whether in Massar International companies that moved there, or in the different shops and entertainment facilities the city provides.
Masri aims for the City of Rawabi to be the [[Silicon Valley]] and the Tech Hub for the [[State of Palestine]],<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.timesofisrael.com/with-all-his-chips-in-palestinian-businessman-aims-to-build-silicon-rawabi/|title=With all his chips in, Palestinian businessman aims to build ‘Silicon Rawabi’|last=|first=|date=|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref> in tireless attempts to provide spaces for promising [[technology]] and technology related [[Startup company|startups]] at the city, and businesses from inside and outside of [[State of Palestine|Palestine]] to the city.
=== Siraj Fund Management Company === Masri founded and manages the first Palestinian equity fund, a 90 million investment initiative known as "Siraj Fund" in 2003, and the company's first fun "Siraj Palestine Fund I" was launched in February 2011,<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/research/stocks/private/snapshot.asp?privcapId=108755386|title=Company Overview of Siraj Fund Management Company|last=|first=|date=|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref> the company was founded for the sole purpose of managing investment funds in Palestine. The company focuses on promising startups and [[capital investments]] in small and medium sized [[Business|enterprises]] in the sectors of [[information]] and [[communication]] [[technology services]], [[energy]], [[agriculture]], [[clean technology]], [[Health care|healthcare]], [[logistics]], [[education]], [[manufacturing]], [[transport]]ation, [[construction]] and [[financial services]]. Siraj's [[investment]]<nowiki/>s in these companies range between $250,000 and $12 million, and plans on expanding in the [[MENA|MENA region]] in the future.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/research/stocks/private/snapshot.asp?privcapId=108755411|title=Company Overview of Siraj Palestine Fund I|last=|first=|date=|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.globes.co.il/en/article-1000622030|title=Siraj Fund raises $60m for Palestinian high tech|last=|first=|date=|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref>
== Awards and Positions == Masri is the former Palestinian Chapter Chairman of the [[Young Presidents' Organization]] (YPO).<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/research/stocks/private/person.asp?personId=111402476&privcapId=107354853&previousCapId=107354853&previousTitle=Massar%20International|title=Bashar Fayeq Masri: Executive Profile & Biography - Bloomberg|last=|first=|date=|website=www.bloomberg.com|access-date=2018-02-21}}</ref> He was named as a "[[Global Leader of Tomorrow]]" by the [[World Economic Forum]].<ref>[http://www.africaintelligence.com/MCE/businessmen/2011/02/17/bashar-masri%2C88135127-BRC-login African intelligence 17/2/2011]</ref> Masri serves on the Board of Directors of the Palestine Development and Investment Company (PADICO),<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.padico.com/en/about-padico/238.html|title=BOARD MEMBER AND A REPRESENTATIVE OF MASSAR INTERNATIONAL INVESTMENT GROUP|last=|first=|date=|website=|access-date=}}</ref> and the Board of Trustees of [[An-Najah National University]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.najah.edu/en/about/governance/board-trustees/|title=Board of trustees|last=|first=|date=|website=|access-date=}}</ref> Masri is a member of the Deans’ Council of the [[John F. Kennedy School of Government]] at [[Harvard University]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.hks.harvard.edu/more/about-us/leadership-administration/deans-office/deans-council|title=Dean's Council|last=|first=|date=|website=|access-date=}}</ref>
Fortune Magazine ranked Masri #38 on its list of "The World's 50 Greatest Leaders".<ref>{{cite web|title=The World's 50 Greatest Leaders|url=http://fortune.com/longform/worlds-greatest-leaders-2018/#bashar|publisher=[[Fortune (magazine)|Fortune]]|accessdate=2018-05-03|language=en|date=April 19, 2018}}</ref>
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== * [http://www.alpha.ps/board/bashar.html Profile]

{{Use dmy dates|date=November 2014}} {{Infobox cricketer | name = Beni Sankar | country = Guyana | image = | fullname = Beni Gopaul Sankar | image_size = | birth_date = {{Birth date and age|1948|9|25|df=yes}} | birth_place = [[Cornelia Ida]], [[British Guiana]] | death_date = | death_place = | nickname = | heightft = | heightinch = | family = | heightm = | batting = Right-handed | bowling = Right-arm [[medium pace|medium]] | role = [[Batsman]] | club1 = [[Essequibo cricket team|Essequibo]] | year1 = 1980 | columns = 1 | column1 = [[First-class cricket|FC]] | matches1 = 1 | runs1 = 22 | bat avg1 = 11.00 | 100s/50s1 = 0/0 | top score1 = 20 | hidedeliveries = | deliveries1 = 6 | wickets1 = 0 | bowl avg1 = n/a | fivefor1 = 0 | tenfor1 = 0 | best bowling1 = 0/4 | catches/stumpings1 = 0/– | date = 1 December | year = 2014 | source = https://cricketarchive.com/Archive/Players/24/24121/24121.html CricketArchive }} '''Beni Gopaul Sankar''' (born 25 September 1948) is a [[Guyana|Guyanese]] businessman and former [[cricket]]er. He captained [[Essequibo cricket team|Essequibo]] in its only [[first-class cricket|first-class]] match, in the final of the 1980–81 inter-county [[Guystac Trophy|Jones Cup]].
Sankar was born at [[Cornelia Ida]], in what is now the [[Essequibo Islands-West Demerara]] region of Guyana, but was then considered to be part of the county of [[Demerara]] in [[British Guiana]].<ref>[https://cricketarchive.com/Archive/Players/24/24121/24121.html Beni Sankar playing statistics] – CricketArchive. Retrieved 1 December 2014.</ref> He is thus the only Essequibo first-class cricketer born outside of Essequibo county.<ref>[https://cricketarchive.com/Archive/Teams/0/698/Players.html Players who have played for Essequibo] – CricketArchive. Retrieved 2 December 2014.</ref> Sankar's father, [[Kayman Sankar]], who died in February 2014, was an [[Indo-Guyanese]] rice magnate, who rose from a labourer to "Guyana’s most successful rice farmer".<ref>(13 February 2014). [http://www.kaieteurnewsonline.com/2014/02/13/kayman-sankar-rice-magnate-dies/ "Kayman Sankar, rice magnate, dies"] – Kaieteur News Online. Retrieved 2 December 2014.</ref> Beni Sankar studied at England's [[National College of Agricultural Engineering]] in [[Silsoe]], [[Bedfordshire]], graduating in 1974, and entered his father's employment, eventually becoming CEO of the Kayman Sankar Group. He was also a director of Demerara Distilleries and Demerara Bank,<ref name="psc">[http://psc.org.gy/about/past-chairs/ Past Chairs] – Private Sector Commission. Retrieved 2 December 2014.</ref> and in the late 2000s helped to establish Guyana's [[aquaculture]] industry, establishing 25 acres of [[fish pond]]s at his father's property in [[Hampton Court, Guyana|Hampton Court]].<ref>[http://www.stabroeknews.com/2010/business/07/09/zeal-and-caution-typify-private-sector-approach-to-aquaculture-sankar/ "Zeal and caution typify private sector approach to aquaculture – Sankar"] – ''StabroekNews.com''. Retrieved 1 December 2014.</ref> Sankar has also served as president of Guyana's Private Sector Commission (from 1994 to 1996), president of [[Georgetown, Guyana|Georgetown]]'s [[Rotary Club]], and chairman of the Caribbean Rice Association.<ref name="psc"/>
Outside of business, Sankar has been keenly involved in [[Sport in Guyana|Guyanese sport]], holding a pilots' licence and serving as a president of the Guyana Table Tennis Association and as a vice-president of the [[Guyana Cricket Board]].<ref name="psc"/> His first-class cricket career was brief, consisting only of a single match for Essequibo.<ref>[https://cricketarchive.com/Archive/Players/24/24121/First-Class_Matches.html First-class matches played by Beni Sankar (1)] – CricketArchive. Retrieved 2 December 2014.</ref> The match was played against [[Berbice cricket team|Berbice]] at the [[Kayman Sankar Cricket Ground]], named for Sankar's father and located near his Hampton Court property. Sankar captained Essequibo, and, playing as a top-order batsman, scored two runs in the first innings and 20 runs in the second innings. He also bowled a single over of right-arm [[medium pace]] in Berbice's second innings, conceding four runs without taking a wicket.<ref name="match">[https://cricketarchive.com/Archive/Scorecards/40/40670.html Essequibo v Berbice], Jones Cup 1980/81 (Final) – CricketArchive. Retrieved 1 December 2014.</ref> Berbice won the match by nine wickets in what was Essequibo's only first-class match – only the final of the three-team Jones Cup (later the Guystac Trophy) was accorded first-class status, and Essequibo made the final only once, having defeated [[Demerara cricket team|Demerara]] in an earlier match.<ref>[https://cricketarchive.com/Archive/Events/2/Jones_Cup_1980-81.html Jones Cup 1980/81] – CricketArchive. Retrieved 1 December 2014.</ref> The scorecards of the non-first-class matches played by Essequibo are not available before the late 1990s, and it is therefore uncertain how Sankar played for Essequibo in other matches.<ref>[https://cricketarchive.com/Archive/Teams/0/698/Other_Matches.html Other matches played by Essequibo] – CricketArchive. Retrieved 1 December 2014.</ref>

[[File:BIOlogovertical.jpg|thumb|right]] {{press release|date=January 2018}} The '''Biotechnology Innovation Organization''' ('''BIO''') is the largest [[trade organization]] in the world that represents the [[biotechnology]] industry.<ref>Anna Edney, [https://www.bloomberg.com/news/2012-06-19/biosciences-defy-u-s-jobs-slump-as-research-labs-hire.html "Biosciences Defy U.S. Jobs Slump as Research Labs Hire"], ''Bloomberg News'', June 19, 2012.</ref><ref>European Biotechnology Network. [http://www.european-biotechnology.net/services/linklist/european-and-international-biotech-industry-associations.html "List of European and International Biotech Industry Associations"]</ref><ref>[http://www.genengnews.com/gen-articles/gen-s-30th-anniversary-biotech-trade-associations/3695/ "GEN's 30th Anniversary: Biotech Trade Associations"], ''Genetic Engineering News'', June 15, 2011.</ref> On January 4, 2016 the Biotechnology Industry Organization changed its name to be the Biotechnology Innovation Organization.<ref>{{Cite web|title = Biotechnology Innovation Organization changes name to Biotechnology Innovation Organization {{!}} Business Wire|url = http://www.businesswire.com/news/home/20160104006245/en/Biotechnology-Industry-Organization-Biotechnology-Innovation-Organization|website = www.businesswire.com|accessdate = 2016-01-04}}</ref>
==Activities== ===Trade meetings=== BIO holds a trade meeting each year in the United States, which are essential for the business development and partnering activities that are required in the biotechnology sector, in which it is expensive to develop products, timelines to develop products are long, and regulatory risks are high.<ref>Robert Weisman, [https://www.bostonglobe.com/business/2013/04/22/biotechnology-executives-from-around-world-gather-chicago-amid-changing-times/Rzvxhh2ZMWW42yh1El3TNJ/story.html "Biopharmaceutical industry faces a shift in dynamics"], ''Boston Globe'', April 23, 2013.</ref> In 2018 the BIO International Convention was held in [[Boston]] and was attended by 18,289 delegates from 49 states, the District of Columbia and Puerto Rico and 67 countries.<ref>BIO Press Office. June 7, 2018 [http://convention.bio.org/content.aspx?id=6875 BIO2018: By The Numbers]</ref> The event also held over 46,916 One-On-One Partnering Meetings, becoming a Guiness World Records, Record Holder for the "Largest Business Partnering Event."<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.bio.org/press-release/bio-sets-guinness-world-records%E2%84%A2-title-largest-business-partnering-event|title=BIO Sets the GUINNESS WORLD RECORDS™ Title for the Largest Business Partnering Event - BIO|website=BIO|language=en|access-date=2018-07-02}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://convention.bio.org/content.aspx?id=6875|title=BIO 2018: By the Numbers {{!}} 2018 BIO International Convention|website=convention.bio.org|access-date=2018-07-02}}</ref>
It also holds regional partnering meetings, for example in [[China]],<ref>[http://www.biosciencetechnology.com/news/2013/04/biotechnology-industry-organization-bio-and-china-center-pharmaceutical-international-exchange-ccpie-announce-strategic-partnership-expand-bio-convention-china#.UbPr4vYaePU "The Biotechnology Innovation Organization (BIO) and the China Center for Pharmaceutical International Exchange (CCPIE) Announce Strategic Partnership to Expand the BIO Convention in China"], BIO Press Office. April 18, 2013</ref> [[India]],<ref>[http://news.thomasnet.com/companystory/BIO-India-Conference-showcases-growing-Indian-biotech-industry-583422 "BIO India Conference showcases growing Indian biotech industry"], BIO Press Release. September 7, 2010.</ref> and Europe.<ref>Staff, Flanders BIO. [http://flandersbio.be/events/bio-europe-2013/ "BIO-Europe® 2013 - 19th Annual International Partnering Meeting"]</ref>
===Lobbying=== In 2013 it spent $1.98 million on [[lobbying]] in the United States.<ref>Staff, The Center for Responsive Politics. [http://www.opensecrets.org/lobby/clientsum.php?id=D000024369 "Lobbying: Biotechnology Innovation Organization"], Page Accessed June 7, 2013</ref> Issues included the amending the [[Internal Revenue Code]] to provide an exception from the passive loss rules for investments in high-technology research small business [[Flow-through entity|pass-through entities]], to include [[vaccine]]s against [[seasonal influenza]] within the definition of taxable vaccines, and to extend, expand, and improve the qualifying therapeutic discovery project program that first became law in 2010.<ref>The Center for Responsive Politics, [http://www.opensecrets.org/lobby/clientbills.php?id=D000024369&year=2013 "Bills lobbied"], Page Accessed June 7, 2013</ref><ref>Drew Armstrong, [https://www.bloomberg.com/news/2010-05-21/biotechnology-drugs-may-earn-5-million-u-s-tax-credit-to-aid-development.html "Promising' Biotechnology Medicines May Earn $5 Million U.S. Tax Credit"], ''Bloomberg News'', May 21, 2010.</ref>
Examples of its public lobbying efforts, include support for development of [[Biofuel|biofuels such as those produced from algae,]]<ref>Kambiz Foroohar for Bloomberg News. June 3, 2010. [https://www.bloomberg.com/news/2010-06-03/exxon-600-million-algae-investment-spurs-khosla-to-dismiss-as-pipe-dream.html Exxon $600 Million Algae Investment Makes Khosla See Pipe Dream]</ref> [[Biofuel|genetically modified crops]],<ref>Elaine Watson, [http://www.foodnavigator-usa.com/People/Biotechnology-Industry-Organization-It-s-not-too-late-to-change-the-conversation-on-GMOs "It's not too late to change the conversation on GMOs: Interview with Cathy Enright, Executive VP for Food and Biotechnology, BIO"], ''Food Navigator'', May 20, 2013.</ref> strong [[intellectual property]] rights,<ref>Victoria Slind-Flor, [https://www.bloomberg.com/news/2012-12-03/lg-dupont-bank-of-america-aero-intellectual-property.html "LG, DuPont, Bank of America, GM: Intellectual Property"], ''Bloomberg News'', December 3, 2012.</ref> and for a more efficient and predictable regulatory process for new food and drug products.<ref>Robert Weisman, [https://www.bostonglobe.com/business/2012/06/18/fda-under-spotlight-biotechnology-industry-organization-bio-convention-opens-boston/JW4lLh22mJwPN5ot2z8MtJ/story.html "Federal drug review nettles biotech industry"], ''Boston Globe'', June 19, 2012.</ref>
===Alliances=== In June 2013 BIO partnered with the [[Coalition of Small Business Innovators]] to lobby the U.S. government to modernize the U.S. tax code "to recognize and promote small business innovation as fundamental to the long-term growth of the U.S. economy".<ref name=CSBI/><ref>[http://www.smallbusinessinnovators.org/page.asp?id=19 "Coalition of Small Business Innovators Official Website"]</ref>
It is a member of The Alliance to Feed the Future, an umbrella network, the mission of which is to "raise awareness and improve understanding of the benefits & necessity of modern food production and technology in order to meet global demand".<ref>[http://www.alliancetofeedthefuture.org/AbouttheAlliance.aspx Alliance to Feed the Future Official Website] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130511040732/http://www.alliancetofeedthefuture.org/AbouttheAlliance.aspx |date=May 11, 2013 }}</ref><ref>PR Web. Monday, March 18, 2013 [http://www.sfgate.com/business/prweb/article/Alliance-to-Feed-the-Future-Congratulates-Our-4364162.php#ixzz2VgNNDSLo "Alliance to Feed the Future Congratulates Our Farmers, Supports Education for Future Generations on National Agriculture Day"]</ref>
==Organization== ===Members=== [[File:James Greenwood 2017 President of Bio DSC8468.JPG | thumb | right | James C. Greenwood, President of BIO, 2017]] BIOs members include companies that make [[Pharmaceutical drugs]], [[biofuels]], [[industrial enzymes]], and [[genetically modified crops]].<ref>[http://www.biospace.com/company_profile.aspx?CompanyId=1311 "BIO profile at Biospace"]</ref> As of 2016, it represents 1,100 biotech companies in all 50 U.S. states, which employ 1.61 million Americans and support an additional 3.4 million jobs.<ref name="CSBI">[http://blog.gcase.org/2013/06/04/biotechnology-industry-organization-joins-coalition-of-small-business-innovators/ "Biotechnology Innovation Organization Joins Coalition of Small Business Innovators"], BIO Press Release, June 4, 2013.</ref>
===Leadership=== BIO was founded 1993 in [[Washington, D.C.]] and [[Carl B. Feldbaum]] was the president from BIO's founding until he retired in 2004,<ref>{{cite press release |title=BIO President Carl Feldbaum to Retire at Year End |publisher=Biotechnology Innovation Organization |date=2 February 2004 |url=http://www.prnewswire.com/cgi-bin/stories.pl?ACCT=104&STORY=/www/story/02-02-2004/0002100951&EDATE= |accessdate=15 July 2009}}</ref> and was succeeded by [[James C. Greenwood]]. As of 2018, John Maraganore, PhD., president and chief executive officer of [[Alnylam Pharmaceuticals]], Inc., was chairman and <ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.alnylam.com/about-alnylam/alnylam-leadership/|title=Our Leadership|last=|first=|date=|website=www.alnylam.com|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|accessdate=2018-07-02}}</ref> James Greenwood was president and CEO.<ref>Staff, BIO [http://www.bio.org/senior-staff BIO Senior Staff] Page Accessed June 7, 2013</ref>
==Biotechnology Heritage Award== The [[Biotechnology Heritage Award]], presented annually at the Biotechnology Innovation Organization (BIO) Annual International Convention by the Biotechnology Innovation Organization (BIO) and the [[Science History Institute]] (formerly the Chemical Heritage Foundation), recognizes individuals who have made significant contributions to the development of biotechnology through discovery, innovation, and public understanding.<ref name=CHF>{{cite web|title= Biotechnology Heritage Award|url=https://www.sciencehistory.org/node/285|website=[[Science History Institute]]|accessdate=21 February 2018}}</ref>
==References==
{{Reflist|20em}}
==External links== * [http://www.bio.org/ BIO Website]
[[Category:Lobbying organizations in the United States]] [[Category:Biotechnology organizations]] [[Category:Life sciences industry]]

revision.comment: Reverted 1 edit by [[Special:Contributions/97.113.151.182|97.113.151.182]] ([[User talk:97.113.151.182|talk]]) to last revision by MaeseLeon. ([[WP:TW|TW]])
revision.text:
{{Other uses}} [[File:Cabin boy ou mousse 1799.jpg|thumb|Cabin boy, 1799]] A '''cabin boy''' or '''ship's boy''' is a [[boy]] (in the sense of low-ranking young male employee, not always a minor in the juridical sense) who waits on the officers and passengers of a [[ship]],<ref>''Concise Oxford Dictionary'', Oxford University Press 1999, entry "Cabin boy"</ref> especially running errands for the captain. ==Duties== Cabin boys were usually 13–16 years old, but sometimes as young as 8,<ref>https://books.google.es/books?id=cVcAAQAAQBAJ&pg=PA174&lpg=PA174&dq=%22cabin+boys%22+%22as+young+as%22&source=bl&ots=MC1-9kyYDS&sig=iTwIO4e4lfK8JqdQSpY3FdPes_g&hl=en&sa=X&ved=2ahUKEwixmbGyxfDcAhUpLsAKHZ2uDFMQ6AEwDXoECAAQAQ#v=onepage&q=%22cabin%20boys%22%20%22as%20young%20as%22&f=false</ref> and also helped the cook in the [[galley (kitchen)|ship's kitchen]] and carried buckets of food from the ship's kitchen to the [[forecastle]] where the ordinary seamen ate. They would have to run from one end of the ship to the other carrying messages and become familiar with the sails, lines and ropes and the use of each in all sorts of weather. They would have to scramble up the rigging into the yards whenever the sails had to be trimmed. They would occasionally stand watch like other crewmen or act as helmsman in good weather, holding the wheel to keep the ship steady on her course.
==Royal Navy officers== Several prominent British Royal Navy officers began their career as cabin boys. The list includes officers that achieved an admiralty rank before 1801. * Admiral of the Fleet [[Sir William Parker, 1st Baronet of Shenstone]] * Admiral of the Fleet Sir [[Cloudsley Shovell]] * Admiral Sir [[Francis Drake]] * Admiral Sir [[John Hawkins (naval commander)|John Hawkins]] * Admiral (General) [[Richard Deane (regicide)|Richard Deane]] * Admiral (Colonel) [[William Rainsborough]] * Admiral Sir [[William Penn (Royal Navy officer)|William Penn]] * Vice Admiral Lord [[Horatio_Nelson,_1st_Viscount_Nelson|Nelson]] * Vice Admiral Sir [[William Batten]] * Vice Admiral Sir [[John Lawson (naval officer)|John Lawson]] * Vice Admiral (Captain) Badilow * Vice Admiral Sir [[Thomas Tiddeman]] * Vice Admiral (Captain) James Peacock * Vice Admiral (Captain) William Goodson * Vice Admiral Sir [[Christopher Myngs]] * Vice Admiral Sir [[John Harman (Royal Navy officer)|John Harman]] * Rear Admiral Sir [[John Berry (Royal Navy officer)|John Berry]] * Rear Admiral Sir [[Richard Stainer]] * Rear Admiral (Captain) Anthony Houlding * Rear Admiral (Captain) Deacons * Rear Admiral (Captain) Robert Sansum
==Notable cabin boys== *[[John Anglin (Medal of Honor)|John Anglin]], cabin boy who received the [[Medal of Honor]] during the [[American Civil War]]. *[[Hobart Bosworth]], cabin boy on the ''[[Sovereign of the Seas (clipper)|Sovereign of the Seas]]'' who became a famous actor. *[[Christian Franzen]], cabin boy who served in the [[Wisconsin State Assembly]].<ref>'Wisconsin Blue Book 1915,' Biographical Sketch of Chris Franzen, pg. 519</ref> *[[Michael A. Healy|Michael Healy]], cabin boy in 1854, who became the first African-American to command a ship of the United States Government. *[[James Machon]], cabin boy who received the [[Medal of Honor]] during the [[American Civil War]]. *[[Thomas Nickerson]], cabin boy on the ''[[Essex (1799 whaleship)|Essex]]'' who later wrote about the shipwreck and subsequent three months of survival at sea. *[[John H. Paynter]], cabin boy who enlisted in 1884, later became a real estate developer and writer of poetry and nonfiction, including the acclaimed ''Fugitive of the Pearl'' (1930). *[[John Ward Westcott]], cabin boy at the age of 13 and a [[Great Lakes]] captain at 20. He developed a special vessel mail system.
==Popular culture== {{Portal|Nautical}} *''[[Cori, de Scheepsjongen]]'' ("Cori the Cabin Boy"), a comics series by Belgian artist [[Bob de Moor]] about a cabin boy working for the [[Verenigde Oostindische Compagnie]] in the 16th century. *''[[Cabin Boy]]'', a 1994 film. *"Cabin Boy" a song by ''[[Tom Robinson]]'' from the 1984/1997 Castaway Northwest CNWVP006 album ''War Baby''. *''[[Captain Pugwash]]'', a British television children's animated series about a hapless captain and his crew; Tom, the cabin boy, is depicted as the most intelligent member of the crew. It is an [[urban myth]] that he was called 'Roger the cabin boy' (a slang sexual meaning of the name [[Roger]]). *''[[Treasure Island]]'', where the main character Jim serves as a cabin boy on the board the ship the ''Hispaniola''. *"Cabin Boy", a short story by [[Damon Knight]]. *''[[Renaissance Festival]]'', The Cabin Boys, Pirate Fire Comedy act from Minnesota.
==References== <references />
{{DEFAULTSORT:Cabin Boy}} [[Category:Personal care and service occupations]] [[Category:Marine occupations]] [[Category:Obsolete occupations]] [[Category:Child labour]] [[Category:Gendered occupations]]
