{{Infobox person | name = Carl Elsener | birth_place = [[Schwyz]], [[Switzerland]] | death_date = {{Death date and age|2013|6|1|1922|7|6}} | death_place = [[Schwyz]], [[Switzerland]] | occupation = Swiss entrepreneur }}
'''Carl Elsener Sr.''' (also known as Charles Elsener, born 6 July 1922 in Ibach, † 1 June 2013<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2013/jul/02/carl-elsener |title=Carl Elsener obituary |date=2 July 2013 |publisher=The Guardian |access-date=29 March 2018}}</ref> in [[Schwyz]]) was a [[Switzerland|Swiss]] [[Entrepreneurship|entrepreneur]].
== Life == Carl Elsener was the grandson of [[Karl Elsener (inventor)|Karl Elsener]] (1860-1918) and the son of Carl Elsener (1886-1950). Karl Elsener had opened a factory in [[Ibach SZ|Ibach]]<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/obituaries/10139841/Carl-Elsener.html |title=Carl Elsener |date=24 June 2013 |publisher=The Telegraph |access-date=29 March 2018}}</ref> for the production of knives and surgical instruments,<ref>{{cite web |url=http://warfarehistorynetwork.com/daily/military-history/the-swiss-army-knife-is-headed-for-the-u-s-army/ |title=The Swiss Army Knife is Headed For the U.S. Army |date=11 July 2017 |publisher=Warfare History |access-date=29 March 2018}}</ref> from which the knife factory [[Victorinox]] developed.
Carl Elsener led the company initially with his father and his brother Eduard Elsener (b. 1926). After the death of his father in 1950, he took over the management.<ref name="A">{{cite web |url=http://beautyinc.world/fashion-style/die-geschichte-von-victorinox |title=Mit Pioniergeist zur Weltmarke – Die Geschichte von Victorinox |publisher=Beautyinc |access-date=29 March 2018}}</ref> The [[Swiss Army Knife]] is considered to be one of his works.<ref name="B">{{cite web |url=http://www.luzernerzeitung.ch/nachrichten/zentralschweiz/schwyz/Carl-Elsener-sen-gestorben;art96,265884 |title=Carl Elsener sen. gestorben |date=3 June 2013 |publisher=Luzerner Zeitung |access-date=29 March 2018}}</ref>
Under the leadership of Carl Elsener Sr., the Messerfabrik became the largest company in the canton of Schwyz. In 1938, Elsener joined the company, which at the time had employed 80 people. At the time of his death, there was well over a thousand employees. Elsener is described as a boss who was able to operate almost all the machines himself, who was traveling in the "[[Cardigan (sweater)|Lismerli]]" or in the [[Smock-frock|blue work coat]] and who cycled to the factory. He never owned a car. A few years before his death, he felt healthy enough to put in an 80-hour week.<ref name="B" />
In October 2000,<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.moneyhouse.ch/de/company/victorinox-stiftung-20917758151 |title=Victorinox-Stiftung |publisher=Moneyhouse |access-date=29 March 2018}}</ref> Elsner founded together with his brother Eduard Elsener and his son Carl Elsener Jr. as a successor solution, the Victorinox Foundation<ref name="A" /> to ensure the continued existence and further prosperity of the company. The Foundation holds 75 percent of the shares of Victorinox AG, another 15 percent belong to the non-profit Carl u. Elise Elsener-Gut Foundation. The Elsener family owns 10 percent of the shares.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.weltwoche.ch/ausgaben/2011_50/artikel/wir-haben-auf-unser-erbe-verzichtet-die-weltwoche-ausgabe-502011.html |title=Wir haben auf unser Erbe verzichtet |date=14 December 2011 |publisher=Die Weltwoche |access-date=29 March 2018}}</ref>
After Carl Elsener Sr. passed away, his son [[Carl Elsener Jr.]] (* 1958) has been managing the company since 2007.
== Awards == * 2011: Cutlery Hall of Fame Award of Magazine [[Blade (magazine)|Blade]].<ref>{{YouTube|id=mNmTBRsR_xs|title="carl elsener jr speaks for the cutlery hall of fame award"}}</ref>
== References == {{Reflist}}
== External links == * [http://www.hls-dhs-dss.ch/textes/d/D25041.php [[Historical Dictionary of Switzerland]]]
{{Authority control}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Elsener, Carl Senior}} [[Category:Victorinox]] [[Category:Swiss businesspeople]] [[Category:People from the canton of Schwyz]] [[Category:1922 births]] [[Category:2013 deaths]]

{{about|the Christchurch central city suburb|the Christchurch Central electorate|Christchurch Central}} {{EngvarB|date=April 2014}} {{Use dmy dates|date=April 2014}} {{Infobox New Zealand suburbs | name = Christchurch Central City | image = Christchurch Square (Christchurch, New Zealand).jpg | caption1 = Cathedral Square – the heart of the central city. The Cathedral suffered heavy damage in the 2011 earthquake, with its tower and part of the main building collapsing. It was announced in September of 2017 that the building would be reinstated. | city1 = Christchurch City Council | city2 = | ward = Hagley-Ferrymead | established = 1850 | area = | population = 4899 | popdate = 30 June 2013 | trainstations = | ferryterminals = | airports = | hospitals = [[Christchurch Hospital]] | north = [[St Albans, New Zealand|St Albans]] | northeast = [[Richmond South]] | east = [[Linwood, New Zealand|Linwood]] | southeast = [[Phillipstown, New Zealand|Phillipstown]] | south = [[Sydenham, New Zealand|Sydenham]] | southwest = [[Addington, New Zealand|Addington]] | west = [[Riccarton, New Zealand|Riccarton]] | northwest = [[Fendalton]] | map = | caption2 = }} '''Christchurch Central City''' is the geographical centre and the heart of [[Christchurch]], New Zealand. It is defined as the area within the four avenues (Bealey Avenue, Fitzgerald Avenue, Moorhouse Avenue and Deans Avenue[http://resources.ccc.govt.nz/files/ResidentialDevelopment-OccupiedDwellings-docs.pdf Christchurch City Council definition]) and thus includes the densely built up central city, some less dense surrounding areas of residential, educational and industrial usage, and green space including [[Hagley Park, Christchurch|Hagley Park]], the [[Christchurch Botanic Gardens]] and the [[Barbadoes Street Cemetery]]. It suffered heavy damage in the [[2010 Canterbury earthquake]] and was devastated in the [[2011 Christchurch earthquake]]. Following this second earthquake, the [[Central City Red Zone]] was set up and, with a gradually shrinking area, remained inaccessible except to authorised contractors until June 2013. However, proposals to relocate the city centre elsewhere, to avoid future damage, were considered both uneconomical (as much of the infrastructure was still mainly intact) and unnecessary, as the rebuilt city centre would be to modern building standards so as to be able to withstand similar quakes and liquefaction in the future.{{cite news|title=City centre stays despite quake|url=http://www.nzherald.co.nz/nz/news/article.cfm?c_id=1&objectid=10732989|accessdate=11 July 2011|newspaper=[[The New Zealand Herald]]|date=18 June 2011|first=Simon|last=Collins}} == Geography == At the centre of the city is [[Cathedral Square, Christchurch|Cathedral Square]], surrounding the [[Anglicanism|Anglican]] cathedral, [[ChristChurch Cathedral, Christchurch|Christ Church]]. The area around this square and within the four avenues of Christchurch is considered the central business district of the city. The city centre is laid out in a grid pattern, interrupted only by the curvilinear alignment of the [[Avon River (Canterbury)|Avon River]], and the two diagonals High Street and Victoria Street. Christchurch has four pairs of one-way streets. The grid pattern within the outermost one-way streets is very regular, as this is the area that was laid out in the original survey. The surrounding area, i.e. the belt between the outer one-way streets and the avenues, was developed later in a progressive fashion and does not have the regularity of the core area. Like most of the city, the centre is relatively flat. == History == ===European settlement=== [[File:Captain Joseph Thomas, 1840.jpg|thumb|upright|left|1840 portrait of Captain [[Joseph Thomas (surveyor)|Joseph Thomas]], the surveyor of [[Lyttelton, New Zealand|Lyttelton]], [[Sumner, New Zealand|Sumner]] and Christchurch]] The European settlement of Christchurch was undertaken by the [[Canterbury Association]], which was founded in London in 1848. That year, the Canterbury Association sent out Captain [[Joseph Thomas (surveyor)|Joseph Thomas]], accompanied by surveyors, to select and prepare a site for settlement. Thomas originally placed the principal town of the proposed settlement at the head of [[Lyttelton Harbour]], but when he realised there was insufficient flat land there to meet the Canterbury Association's requirements, he relocated Christchurch to where he had previously placed a town called 'Stratford' at a point on the Avon where those coming up the river first encountered slightly higher, drier ground.{{cite web | url = http://resources.ccc.govt.nz/files/ChristchurchCityContextualHistoryOverviewFull-docs.pdf | title = Contextual Historical Overview for Christchurch City| type = PDF}} Back then, the Avon River was navigable as far as 'The Bricks' just upstream of the Barbadoes Street bridge. The site is these days marked by a riverbank cairn. The site got its name when the Deans Brothers in the 1840s had shipped bricks for their [[Riccarton, New Zealand|Riccarton]] homestead up the Avon River, which they unloaded in this location. [[File:TheBricks.png|thumb|The Bricks on the southern bank of the Avon River. One of the huts is believed to have belonged to Joseph Thomas. The inserts show the First Four Ships that landed the colonists in 1850. Painted by John Dury in 1851.]] ===Survey layout=== [[File:Christchurch Survey 969.jpg|thumb|Plaque in [[Cathedral Square, Christchurch|Cathedral Square]] commemorating the Christchurch survey]] Christchurch is one of a group of only four cities in the world that have been carefully planned following the same layout of a central city square, four complimenting city squares surrounding it and a parklands area that embrace the city centre. The first city built with this pattern was [[Philadelphia]], later came [[Oglethorpe Plan|Savannah]] and [[Adelaide]]. The fourth city using this pattern was Christchurch. As such Christchurch holds an important legacy and a strong platform for future development. Thomas' plan for Christchurch (laid out by the surveyor [[Edward Jollie]] by March 1850) was the 'standard' rectangular grid of colonial settlement (adopted for ease of survey and to facilitate land sales). Thomas did not allow Jollie to include crescents to provide variety, but the Avon River ran eccentrically across the site. Two diagonal streets (High Street/Ferry Road leading to [[Ferrymead]], [[Heathcote Valley|Heathcote]] and [[Sumner, New Zealand|Sumner]] and Victoria Street/Papanui Road leading to the [[Papanui]] Bush) also broke the regularity of the grid. At the very centre of the city was a 'Square' (which is actually cross-shaped) intended as a grand centre for the city and the site of the proposed cathedral and grammar school. East and north-west of the Square were two more 'squares' ([[Latimer Square|Latimer]] and [[Cranmer Square]]s, which are actually rectangles) which were placed more or less regularly in relation to the diagonal line of the Avon running in a north-easterly direction across the city to the west and north of the central square. The grid was laid out originally between Salisbury Street to the north and St Asaph Street to the south and between Barbadoes Street to the east and Rolleston Avenue/Park Terrace to the west. Between Salisbury, Barbadoes and St Asaph Streets and (respectively) the North, East and South Town Belts (these days called Bealey, Fitzgerald and Moorhouse Avenues) were 'town reserves', i.e. land with-held from immediate sale, which was sold off by the Provincial Government later in the 1850s to overcome cash flow problems. The streets of the original grid were mostly projected out to the Town Belts, but the street system is less systematic in the former 'town reserves'. The names chosen for the streets of the inner city almost all commemorate the English colonial origins of the settlement. The names chosen later for the town belts commemorate important personalities of early Christchurch. Jollie explains in his diary how the streets got their names:{{cite web|title=6. Christchurch: 1849–1851 |url= http://sites.google.com/site/marapito/jollie_06 |publisher=Canterbury Heritage |accessdate=6 June 2010}}
The names of the streets of the three towns I surveyed were taken from Bishoprics and the way it was done was this; as soon as I completed the map I took it to Thomas who putting on his gold spectacles and opening his would read out a Bishop's name to hear if it sounded well. If I agreed with him that it did, I put the name to one of the streets requiring baptism. Lyttelton being the first born town got the best names for its streets, Sumner being next had the next best and Christchurch being the youngest had to be content with chiefly Irish and Colonial bishoprics as names for its streets. This accounts for, what to anyone not knowing the circumstances, appears strange, viz: that many of the best English Bishoprics are not represented while Irish and Colonial ones are. Sumner in fact died too late for the names there used to be again employed in Christchurch.
The original plan from 1850 shows the north-west corner of the 'town reserves' (surrounded by the Avon River, Fitzgerald and Bealey Avenues and Barbadoes Street, with an additional small rectangular area to the west of Barbadoes Street) as the cemetery for the settlement. Individual town sections were shown on the survey plan, the Black Map, and numbered by the surveyors in a logical order, in contrast to the rural sections surrounding Christchurch, which were numbered at the time of and in the order of their purchase.{{cite news |title=Rural Sections Chosen |url= http://paperspast.natlib.govt.nz/cgi-bin/paperspast?a=d&d=LT18510301.2.13 |accessdate=16 March 2013 |newspaper=[[Lyttelton Times]] |volume=I |issue=8 |date=1 March 1851 |page=6}} The following streets were those laid out in the 1850 survey (listed east to west, then north to south, then diagonals). Where a street name is one of the original names as devised by surveyors Joseph Thomas and Edward Jollie, this is marked as such. ====Streets running north-south==== [[File:Black Map Christchurch 1850.jpg|thumb|Christchurch Black Map from March 1850]] * Deans Avenue – the original name for this street was West Belt. In 1905, it got renamed to Rolleston Avenue, but was called West Belt again in 1906. Deans Avenue is named after the Deans family, who farmed at Riccarton from 1843 onwards.{{cite web|url=http://christchurchcitylibraries.com/Heritage/PlaceNames/ChristchurchStreetNames-C-E.pdf|title=Christchurch Street Names C to E|last=Harper|first=Margaret |publisher=[[Christchurch City Libraries]]|pages=7, 8, 24, 107, 137, 173, 218|accessdate=17 January 2010}} * Harper Avenue – this street was formerly called Park Road and North Park Road. It was so named because it runs alongside Hagley Park. It was renamed Harper Avenue by city council resolution on 18 May 1931 in honour of the retiring chairman of the ''Christchurch Domains Board'' George Harper (1843–1937).{{cite web|url=http://christchurchcitylibraries.com/Heritage/PlaceNames/ChristchurchStreetNames-F-K.pdf|title=Christchurch Street Names F to K|last=Harper|first=Margaret |publisher=[[Christchurch City Libraries]]|pages=19, 25, 68, 85, 154, 194, 199, 303|accessdate=17 January 2010}} * Rolleston Avenue – this street formerly belonged to Antigua Street. The section between Cambridge Terrace and Armagh Street was renamed in honour of [[William Rolleston]] on 11 January 1903, about one month before his passing. This street was chosen because of his association with Canterbury College (now the [[Christchurch Arts Centre]], which adjoined Antigua Street and also because it was proposed to erect [[Rolleston Statue|his statue]] there.{{cite web|url=http://christchurchcitylibraries.com/Heritage/PlaceNames/ChristchurchStreetNames-R-S.pdf|title=Christchurch Street Names R to S|last=Harper|first=Margaret |publisher=[[Christchurch City Libraries]]|pages=51, 85, 171|accessdate=17 January 2010}} * Park Terrace – this street appears as Mill Road on an 1862 map. Park Terrace, named because it runs adjacent to Hagley Park, first appears in street directories in 1880.{{cite web|url=http://christchurchcitylibraries.com/Heritage/PlaceNames/ChristchurchStreetNames-L-Q.pdf|title=Christchurch Street Names L to Q|last=Harper|first=Margaret |publisher=[[Christchurch City Libraries]]|pages=13, 32, 75, 92, 177, 180, 271, 286, 309|accessdate=17 January 2010}} * Cranmer Square (original street name) – Cranmer Square is adjacent to the square of the same name and is named after the martyred [[Oxford]] bishop [[Thomas Cranmer]]. * Montreal Street (original street name) – this street is named after the [[Anglican Diocese of Montreal]] in Canada. The surveyors ran out of English bishoprics to use as street names so moved on to other colonies. * Durham Street (original street name) – the street was named after the [[Diocese of Durham]]. On 21 October 1985 the council resolved for the two separate sections of Durham Street (between Gloucester Street and Cashel Street, which is part of Cambridge Terrace) to be renamed Durham Street North and South. * [[Colombo Street]] (original street name) – this street is named after the colonial Anglican bishopric [[Colombo]] in what at the time was known as [[Sri Lanka|Ceylon]]. * Manchester Street (original street name) – this street is named after [[William Montagu, 7th Duke of Manchester]], who was a member of the Canterbury association in 1848. * Latimer Square (original street name) – the street adjacent to Latimer Square is named after the martyred [[Oxford]] bishop [[Hugh Latimer]]. * Madras Street (original street name) – this street is named after the colonial Anglican bishopric of [[Chennai|Madras]] (now known as Chennai) in [[India]]. * Barbadoes Street (original street name) – this street is named after the Anglican colonial [[Diocese of Barbados]] in the [[Caribbean|West Indies]], now known as the Caribbean. The Christchurch spelling of Barbados with an additional 'e' is as per the original survey plan drawn by Edward Jollie.{{cite web|url=http://christchurchcitylibraries.com/Heritage/PlaceNames/ChristchurchStreetNames-A-B.pdf|title=Christchurch Street Names A to B|last=Harper|first=Margaret |publisher=[[Christchurch City Libraries]]|pages=49, 118, 154|accessdate=17 January 2010}} * Fitzgerald Ave – the original names for this street were East Town Belt and East Belt. The street was renamed by council on 11 January 1904 in honour of [[James FitzGerald (New Zealand politician)|James FitzGerald]]. [[File:High, Manchester and Lichfield Streets in Christchurch, 8 May 1923.jpg|thumb|Intersection of High, Manchester and Lichfield Streets, Christchurch, 8 May 1923]] ====Streets running east-west==== * Bealey Avenue – the original name for this street was North Belt and North Town Belt. On 11 January 1904, it got renamed in honour of Canterbury's third [[Superintendent (politics)|Superintendent]] [[Samuel Bealey]], who owned land in this area. * Salisbury Street (original street name) – the street is named after the English [[Diocese of Salisbury]]. * Peterborough Street (original street name) – the street is named after the [[Anglican Diocese of Peterborough]]. * Kilmore Street (original street name) – the street is named after the Irish [[Diocese of Kilmore, Elphin and Ardagh|Diocese of Kilmore]]. * Chester Street (original street name) – the street is named after the English Anglican [[Diocese of Chester]]. It appears in 1883 street directories as Chester Street between East Town Belt and Colombo Street, and Chester Street West between Cambridge Terrace and Park Terrace. Chester Street West was renamed Cranmer Terrace for a short time in the 1950s because of the gap in Chester Street between Colombo Street and Cambridge Terrace. It reverted to its earlier name when the residents found that there was confusion with Cranmer Square. * Armagh Street (original street name) – the street is named after the [[Diocese of Armagh (Church of Ireland)|Diocese of Armagh]]. * Gloucester Street (original street name) – the street is named after the [[Diocese of Gloucester]]. [[File:View looking west-south-west from the Cathedral Tower, Christchurch.jpg|left|thumb|Worcester Street and Cathedral Square from the ChristChurch Cathedral]] * Worcester Street (original street name) – the street is named after the [[Anglican Diocese of Worcester]].{{cite web|url=http://christchurchcitylibraries.com/Heritage/PlaceNames/ChristchurchStreetNames-T-Z.pdf|title=Christchurch Street Names T to Z|last=Harper|first=Margaret |publisher=[[Christchurch City Libraries]]|pages=58, 84, 170|accessdate=17 January 2010}} * Hereford Street (original street name) – the street is named after the [[Diocese of Hereford]]. * Cashel Street (original street name) – the street is named after the [[Bishop of Cashel and Waterford|bishopric of Cashel]]. * Lichfield Street (original street name) – the street is named after the [[Diocese of Lichfield]]. * Tuam Street (original street name) – the street is named after the Irish [[Diocese of Tuam, Killala and Achonry|Diocese of Tuam]]. * St Asaph Street (original street name) – the street is named after the [[Diocese of St Asaph]] in Wales. * Moorhouse Avenue – the original name for this street was South Belt and South Town Belt. On 11 January 1904, it got renamed in honour of Canterbury's second superintendent [[William Sefton Moorhouse]], who had championed the development of [[Lyttelton Line|Christchurch-Lyttelton railway]] and the [[Lyttelton rail tunnel]]. It was thus thought appropriate that the avenue adjacent to the railway be named after him. ====Other streets==== * Cambridge Terrace (original street name) – the street is named after the [[University of Cambridge]] in England. Waterloo Terrace was the name on the first plan of the road along the Avon River from Market Place (now Victoria Square) to past the Foresters' Hall, i.e. from near the Oxford-on-Avon and the [[Plunket Society]] round to near the Centennial Leisure Centre. Avonside Road was the section just south of the Barbadoes Street Cemetery, adjacent to the river bank and the river, across the river from the Avon Loop, east of Barbadoes Street and round to Fitzgerald Avenue. * Oxford Terrace (original street name) – the street is named after the [[University of Oxford]]. [[John Robert Godley]], considered to be the founder of Christchurch, had studied at [[Christ Church, Oxford|Christ Church]], one of the colleges of the University of Oxford. * [[Victoria Street (Christchurch)|Victoria Street]] – this street was originally named Whately Road after [[Richard Whately]], who was a member of the Canterbury Association. It was renamed Victoria Street in 1877 after a petition signed by 61 residents was presented asking that the name be changed. The current street name commemorates [[Queen Victoria]]. * High Street – this street was originally named Sumner Road, as it connected to the village of Sumner. At the time, Sumner was of great importance to Christchurch, as a road over the [[Port Hills]] was to be built connecting [[Lyttelton, New Zealand|Lyttelton]] with Sumner. The section north of St Asaph Street was renamed High Street. * Ferry Road – the CBD end of Ferry Road was originally called Sumner Road. The section south of St Asaph Street was renamed Lower High Street, and then Ferry Road. ===Important Canterbury Association members=== The prime movers of the Canterbury Association were [[Edward Gibbon Wakefield]] and John Robert Godley. Godley, with his family, went out to New Zealand in early 1850 to oversee the preparations for the settlement (surveying, roads, accommodation, etc.) undertaken by Captain Joseph Thomas' team. These preparations were advanced, but incomplete when the first ships of settlers arrived on 16 December 1850, having been halted by Godley shortly after his arrival in April due to the mounting debts of the Association. The ''[[Charlotte-Jane]]'' and ''[[Randolph (ship)|Randolph]]'' arrived in Lyttelton Harbour on the 16th, {{ship||Sir George Seymour|1844 ship|2}} on the 17th, and ''[[Cressy (ship)|Cressy]]'' on the 27th, having set sail from England in September 1850. The settlers on these [[First Four Ships]] were dubbed the ''Canterbury Pilgrims'' by the British press. A further 24 shiploads of Canterbury Association settlers, making a total of approximately 3,500, arrived over the next two and a half years.[http://freepages.genealogy.rootsweb.com/~nzbound/cbyassoc.htm Canterbury Association]. ===2010/11 earthquakes=== The central city was among the most heavily damaged areas of Christchurch following the [[2010 Canterbury earthquake]]. Many building façades collapsed into the streets and authorities cordoned off large areas of the central city following the event. [[Manchester Courts]], the tallest commercial building in Christchurch when it was built in 1905–06 and a Category I heritage building suffered serious structural damage and was the first major building that was demolished, with the demolition finishing just days before the [[2011 Christchurch earthquake]].{{cite news|last=Conway |first=Glenn |title=Demolition for historic high-rise |url=http://www.stuff.co.nz/the-press/news/christchurch/4205226/Demolition-for-historic-high-rise |accessdate=7 October 2010 |newspaper=[[The Press]]|date=7 October 2010 |page=A3}} Nearly six months later on Tuesday 22 February 2011, [[2011 Christchurch earthquake|a second earthquake]] measuring magnitude 6.3 struck the city at 12:51 pm. It was located closer to the city,{{Cite web |title=New Zealand Earthquake Report – Feb 22, 2011 at 12:51 pm (NZDT) |work=[[GeoNet]] |publisher=[[Earthquake Commission]] and [[GNS Science]] |url=http://www.geonet.org.nz/earthquake/quakes/3468575g.html |date=22 February 2011 |accessdate=22 February 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110223092531/http://www.geonet.org.nz/earthquake/quakes/3468575g.html |archivedate=23 February 2011 |df=dmy-all }} and although lower on the [[moment magnitude scale]] than the previous earthquake, the intensity and violence of the ground shaking was measured to be IX (''Violent'') on the [[Mercalli intensity scale]], and was among the strongest ever recorded globally in an urban area{{cite news |url= http://www.stuff.co.nz/dominion-post/news/4714748/Building-code-no-match-for-earthquake |title=Building code no match for earthquake |first=Andrea |last=Fox |work=The Dominion Post |date=1 March 2011 |accessdate=11 July 2011}}{{failed verification|date=November 2015}} and in total 185 people were killed{{cite web |url= http://www.stuff.co.nz/national/6394084/February-earthquake-toll-hits-185 |title= Official quake toll rises to 185 |date= 9 February 2012 |publisher= Stuff.co |accessdate= 9 February 2012}}{{cite web |url= http://www.police.govt.nz/list-deceased |title= List of deceased – Christchurch earthquake |publisher=New Zealand Police |date= 8 September 2011 |accessdate=26 December 2011}} with nationals from more than 20 countries among the victims.{{cite news|title=Earthquake toll rises to 145|url=http://www.nzherald.co.nz/nz/news/article.cfm?c_id=1&objectid=10708888|accessdate=26 February 2011|newspaper=New Zealand Herald|date=26 February 2011}} [[ChristChurch Cathedral, Christchurch|ChristChurch Cathedral]] lost its spire{{cite web |title=Large quake strikes Christchurch |url= http://www.stuff.co.nz/4688231/Large-quake-strikes-Christchurch |work=Dominion Post |accessdate=22 February 2011 |year=2011}}{{cite news |url= http://www.nzherald.co.nz/nz/news/article.cfm?c_id=1&objectid=10708016 |title=Christchurch quake: People likely to be trapped in cathedral |newspaper=New Zealand Herald |date=22 February 2011 |accessdate=22 February 2011}} and widespread damage was caused to city buildings already weakened by 4 September 2010 earthquake and its aftershocks. A large number of heritage buildings have been demolished since the earthquake, and most of the [[List of tallest buildings in Christchurch|city's high rise buildings]], including [[Hotel Grand Chancellor, Christchurch|Hotel Grand Chancellor]], [[PricewaterhouseCoopers, Christchurch|PricewaterhouseCoopers]], [[Clarendon Tower]], and [[Implosion of Radio Network House|Radio Network House]] have been demolished. Many churches have been demolished following the earthquakes, including [[Durham Street Methodist Church]], [[Oxford Terrace Baptist Church]], [[St Luke's Church, Christchurch]], [[St Paul's Church, Christchurch|St Paul's Church]], and [[St John the Baptist Church, Christchurch|St John the Baptist Church]]. Other churches are badly damaged and their fate is undecided, including the [[Cathedral of the Blessed Sacrament, Christchurch|Cathedral of the Blessed Sacrament]] and the Anglican [[ChristChurch Cathedral, Christchurch|ChristChurch Cathedral]]. A replacement Anglican cathedral, the [[Cardboard Cathedral]], opened in August 2013 on the site of the former St John the Baptist Church.{{cite news |last=Stewart |first=Ashleigh |title=Emotional moment for bishop at handover of new cathedral |url= http://www.stuff.co.nz/the-press/news/8996908/Bishop-keyed-up-at-cardboard-cathedral-handover-ceremony |accessdate=3 August 2013 |newspaper=[[The Press]] |date=3 August 2013 |page=A3 |location=[[Christchurch]]}} == Characteristics == [[File:Hagley Park 01.jpg|thumb|Aerial view of the central city in July 2012, with many of the earthquake-damaged [[List of tallest buildings in Christchurch|tall building]]s still standing]] === Overview === The Central City offered well over 450 unique retail businesses and over 130 cafes, restaurants, bars and clubs. It had the largest selection of fashion, food, café and entertainment in the [[South Island]].http://www.christchurchcity.org.nz/index.php Central City Business Association website The central city has a number of residential areas, including Inner City East, Inner City West, Avon Loop, Moa Neighbourhood & Victoria. South of Tuam Street, commercial usage and some light industries are present. With over 6,000 full-time equivalent students, the [[Christchurch Polytechnic Institute of Technology]] is the major education provider in the city centre. Cathedral Square was a popular destination and hosts attractions such as the speakers' corner made famous by the [[Wizard of New Zealand]], Ian Brackenbury Channell, and evangelist [[Ray Comfort]]. A [[Christchurch tramway system|central city heritage tram]] system has been operated since 1995. In 2010, the system was extended to the south to form a figure of eight. The tram system does not fulfil a transport function and is aimed at the tourism market. In 2010 the Christchurch City Council released "A City For People Action Plan", a program of work through to 2022 to improve public spaces within the central city to entice more inner city residents and visitors. A primary action is to reduce the impact of motorised private vehicles and increase the comfort of pedestrians and cyclists. The plan is based on a report prepared for the council by renowned Danish design firm Gehl Architects. === Precincts === The central city includes the pedestrianised Cashel and High Streets, known as [[City Mall, Christchurch|City Mall]]. At one end of the mall stands the [[Bridge of Remembrance]]; at the intersection of Cashel and High Streets is the old location of the amphitheatre known as the [[Hack Circle]]; and the portion of High Street up to the junction of Colombo and Hereford Streets forms the remaining part of the mall. The concept of a pedestrian mall originated in 1965 as part of a central city redevelopment study. The project was publicly notified in the 1968 District Scheme, and again in the 1979 review. In 1981, the Christchurch City Council, in collaboration with the Cashel and High Street Businessmen's Associations, adopted a design and authorised implementation. The streets were closed to traffic on 11 January 1982 and the Mall was opened by the former Mayor, Sir [[Hamish Hay]], on 7 August 1982. [[File:New Zealand Christchurch Bridge of rememberence.jpg|thumb|The [[Bridge of Remembrance]] in Cashel Street]] On 17 December 2009, a revamped City Mall was opened by mayor [[Bob Parker (mayor)|Bob Parker]], incorporating the tourist tram through the mall.{{cite news |url= http://www.stuff.co.nz/national/3173714/Christchurch-mall-revamp-injects-new-life |title=City Mall revamp opened |last=Conway |first=Glenn |date=18 December 2009 |publisher=The Press |page=A3 |accessdate=20 January 2010 |location=Christchurch}} The Bridge of Remembrance was opened on Armistice Day, 11 November 1924 by the Governor-General, Admiral of the Fleet, Lord Jellicoe, who had previously laid the foundation stone on Anzac Day, 25 April 1923. The road through the bridge was removed and the short stretch between Oxford Terrace and Cambridge Terrace opened as a pedestrian precinct on 25 April 1977 (Anzac Day) by Captain [[Charles Upham]], i.e. this stretch became a pedestrian precinct some five years before the establishment of City Mall.http://christchurchcitylibraries.com/Heritage/Places/Memorials/BridgeofRemembrance/ Christchurch City Libraries information on the Bridge of Remembrance Another pedestrianised street is [[New Regent Street]], which has building facades in the Spanish Mission style. It became a pedestrian mall as part of the heritage tram loop in 1995. The street survived the earthquake with little damage, and is now functioning with several shops, and appearances by the Wizard of New Zealand. [[File:Shops in New Regent Street.jpg|left|thumb|Spanish Mission building frontages in New Regent Street]] Prior to the earthquakes, the [[Christchurch City Council]] was considering turning a section of Oxford Terrace (the section between Cashel Street and Hereford Street, then known as ''[[The Strip (Christchurch)|The Strip]]'') into a part-time pedestrian mall (nightly from 11 pm to 5 am).{{cite web|title=Oxford Terrace part-time pedestrian mall proposal|url= http://www1.ccc.govt.nz/council/agendas/2009/july/hagleyferrymead15th/hagleyferrymeadcommunityboardagenda15july2009.pdf |publisher=[[Christchurch City Council]] |accessdate=5 July 2013 |format=PDF |date=15 July 2009}} Since around 2005, two precincts have developed in small central city lanes, known as ''Poplar Lane'' and ''South of Lichfield'' or ''SOL Square''. A large number of bars are accommodated in these two areas, with a very active night life. These areas complement ''The Strip'', a part of Oxford Terrace that started to support outdoor dining during the day and night time entertainment in the 1990s. The Cultural Precinct [http://www.culturalprecinct.co.nz/] provides a backdrop to a vibrant scene of ever-changing arts, cultural, and heritage attractions within an area of less than one square kilometre. The [[Christchurch Arts Centre|Arts Centre]], the [[Canterbury Museum, Christchurch|Canterbury Museum]], the [[Christchurch Art Gallery]] and the [[Centre of Contemporary Art]] (CoCA) are located in the Cultural Precinct. The majority of the activities are free. === Heritage buildings === The central city has a large number of registered heritage buildings that are either listed with [[Heritage New Zealand]] or are noted in the Christchurch City Plan. A large number of these buildings have been significantly damaged by the recent earthquakes. Some heritage buildings collapsed during the February earthquake (e.g. the Stone Chamber of the [[Canterbury Provincial Council Buildings]]{{cite news |last=Sachdeva |first=Sam |title=People first, buildings take a back seat |newspaper=[[The Press]] |date=26 February 2011 |author2=Moore, Christopher |location=Christchurch |page=A22}}), many have been demolished already (e.g. [[St Elmo Courts]],{{cite news|last=Brown|first=Giles|title=Heritage building too damaged to save |url= http://www.stuff.co.nz/the-press/news/4789954/Heritage-building-too-damaged-to-save |accessdate=21 March 2011 |newspaper=[[The Press]] |date=21 March 2011 |author2=Keith Lynch |page=A3}} [[The Press Building, Christchurch|The Press Building]]{{cite news|last=Lynch|first=Keith|title=More than 128 Christchurch buildings face demolition |url= http://www.stuff.co.nz/the-press/news/christchurch-earthquake-2011/4838607/More-than-128-Christchurch-buildings-face-demolition |accessdate=2 April 2011|newspaper=[[The Press]] |date=2 April 2011}} or [[St Luke's Church, Christchurch|St Luke's Church]]{{cite news|title=St Luke's is being demolished |url= http://www.stuff.co.nz/the-press/news/christchurch-earthquake-2011/5244018/St-Lukes-is-being-demolished |accessdate=6 June 2012|newspaper=[[The Press]]|date=6 July 2011}}), and for many heritage buildings, the fate is as yet unclear (e.g. the [[Peterborough Centre]].{{cite news|last=Heather|first=Ben|title=Owners vow to save historic edifice|url= http://www.stuff.co.nz/the-press/news/christchurch-earthquake-2011/5119007/Owners-vow-to-save-historic-edifice |accessdate=18 June 2011|newspaper=[[The Press]] |date=9 June 2011}}) [[McLean's Mansion]] in Manchester Street, a 53-room dwelling built in 1900 for 78-year-old bachelor [[Allan McLean (philanthropist)|Allan McLean]], is currently threatened with demolition.{{cite web |title=McLeans Mansion |url= http://christchurchcitylibraries.com/Heritage/Publications/ChristchurchCityCouncil/ArchitecturalHeritage/McLeansMansion/McLeansMansion.pdf |publisher=[[Christchurch City Council]] Town Planning Division |accessdate=18 July 2013 |location=[[Christchurch]] |format=PDF |date=June 1983}}{{cite news |title=Editorial: McLean's Mansion should be saved |url= http://www.stuff.co.nz/the-press/opinion/editorials/8921485/Editorial-McLeans-Mansion-should-be-saved |accessdate=18 July 2013 |newspaper=[[The Press]] |date=16 July 2013}} === Population === [[File:Central City Population.jpg|thumb|Comparing extrapolated historic growth in resident population with required growth to reach 30,000 residents by 2026.]] The central city prior to the 2010-2011 earthquakes had an increasing residential population. The last four [[New Zealand census]]es had the usual resident population on 30 June recorded as follows:{{cite web |title=Statistics NZ |url=http://www.stats.govt.nz/StatsMaps/Home/People%20and%20households/2013-census-population-dwelling-map.aspx |publisher=Stats NZ |accessdate=28 October 2017}} {| border="1" |+ Census resident population | align="center" style="background:#f0f0f0;" width="120"|'''Census''' | align="center" style="background:#f0f0f0;" width="50"|'''1996''' | align="center" style="background:#f0f0f0;" width="50"|'''2001''' | align="center" style="background:#f0f0f0;" width="50"|'''2006''' | align="center" style="background:#f0f0f0;" width="50"|'''2013''' |- | align="center" | Resident population |align="right" |6600 |align="right" |7369 |align="right" |7653 |align="right" |4899 |} The Christchurch City Council alongside Otakaro Limited is trying to revitalise the central city. The Council aspires to have 30,000 residents living within the Four Avenues by 2026.http://resources.ccc.govt.nz/files/ThePress20080816-ourchristchurch.pdf Central city population mentioned in CCC newsletterhttp://www.greaterchristchurch.org.nz/Strategy/UDSSummary2008.pdf Central city population mentioned in Urban Development Strategy document When the historic census population (for 1996, 2001 and 2006) is plotted and extrapolated to 2026, and compared to the required growth to reach a projected population of 30,000 residents by 2026, it becomes clear that this is an ambitious goal. Entire city blocks have been earmarked for residential development,{{cite web |title=East Frame Pūtahi Whakaterāwhiti |url=https://www.otakaroltd.co.nz/anchor-projects/the-east-frame/ |publisher=Otakaro Limited |accessdate=28 October 2017}} as well as private developments,{{cite news |title=Fletchers to build 191 inner-city homes for Christchurch |url=http://www.stuff.co.nz/the-press/business/your-property/68403229/fletchers-to-build-191-innercity-homes-for-christchurch |publisher=Stuff |accessdate=28 October 2017}} aiming toward this goal. === Economy === The central city is an important employment area supporting 26,000 [[full-time equivalent]] (FTE) employees, and with much of the floor area taken up by office space. One of the biggest employers is Christchurch City Council with 800 FTE at the civic offices.http://www.aucklandcity.govt.nz/council/projects/cbdproject/docs/demographicandemploymentdata.pdf Employment data The southern part of the central city has traditionally been home to manufacturing, but there has been a decline in this area, with many companies either moving to commercial subdivisions, closing, or relocating overseas. === Education === Many education providers are located in the city centre. Christchurch Polytechnic with 6000 students is the largest of these. There are numerous language schools, providing a platform for an important market of attracting mainly Asian students to the city. There are several schools in the central city. [[File:Christ's College entrance.jpg|thumb|Main entrance of Christ's College]] * [[Christ's College, Christchurch|Christ's College]] is an independent, [[Anglicanism|Anglican]], secondary, [[Day school|day]] and [[boarding school]] for boys. Founded in 1850 at [[Lyttelton, New Zealand|Lyttelton]] as a school for early settlers, Christ's is the oldest independent school in the country.{{cite web|url= http://www.christscollege.com/history.html|title= History|accessdate= 6 December 2009|work= About Us|publisher= Christ's College|deadurl= yes|archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20070909012924/http://www.christscollege.com/history.html|archivedate= 9 September 2007|df= dmy-all}} The college currently caters for approximately 647 students from Year 9 to Year 13. [[Christ's College Big School]] is the oldest education building in continuous use in New Zealand.{{cite book |last=Wilson |first=John|title=City and Peninsula: The Historic Places of Christchurch and Banks Peninsula |year=2007 |publisher=The Christchurch Civic Trust / The Akaroa Civic Trust| location=Christchurch |isbn=978-0-473-12239-3 |edition=first |page=111}} * [[St Michael's Church School]] is a co-educational Anglican primary and intermediate day school. * [[Hagley Community College]] is a non-integrated state secondary school. Prior to 1965 the school was Christchurch West High School, which was founded in 1858. * The [[Cathedral Grammar School]] is an independent, Anglican preparatory day school. It was founded in 1881 to educate 24 scholarship boys, who sang in the choir of Christchurch Cathedral. It is one of only a small number of 'choir schools' in the [[Southern Hemisphere]]. * [[Unlimited Paenga Tawhiti]] (UPT) is a state secondary school based in the heart of the Christchurch Central Business District. It was established in 2003 by the Christchurch-based Learning Discovery Trust,http://www.discoverylearning.co.nz/index.html Official website of the Learning Discovery Trust which had earlier set up the Discovery 1 school. * [[Discovery 1 School]] is a special character, state funded primary school based in the heart of the Christchurch Central Business District. It is an innovative learning community where all key stakeholders (children, parents & staff) take an active part in the creation of a child's learning journey.{{cite web|url=http://www.discovery1.school.nz/ |title=Archived copy |accessdate=10 January 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081228030559/http://www.discovery1.school.nz/ |archivedate=28 December 2008 }} Discovery 1 official website * [[Christchurch East School]] is a non-integrated state co-educational primary school.http://www.tki.org.nz/e/schools/display_school_info.php?school_id=3317 Information on Christchurch East School * [[Catholic Cathedral College]] is an integrated co-educational secondary school. It was founded in 1987 from the amalgamation of two schools: Sacred Heart College for girls, and Xavier College for boys. === Green space === [[File:HagleyPark02 gobeirne.jpg|left|thumb|Late afternoon in Hagley Park]] Hagley Park is, at 165 ha, the largest [[urban open space]] in Christchurch. The park was created in 1855 by the Provincial Government.http://resources.ccc.govt.nz/files/HagleyParkMgtPlan2007_ALL_LR-popularparks.pdf Hagley Park Management Plan According to the government's decree at that time, Hagley Park is "reserved forever as a public park, and shall be open for the recreation and enjoyment of the public." Hagley Park is characterised by its trees and broad open spaces. Hagley Park was named after the country estate of [[George Lyttelton, 4th Baron Lyttelton|Lord Lyttelton]], who became chairman of the Canterbury Association in March 1850.http://freepages.genealogy.rootsweb.ancestry.com/~nzbound/cby.htm Information on Lord Lyttelton The Christchurch Botanic Gardens are botanical gardens founded in 1863,{{cite web |url=http://www.ccc.govt.nz/cityleisure/parkswalkways/christchurchbotanicgardens/index.aspx |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2016-04-30 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20091019082224/http://www.ccc.govt.nz/cityleisure/parkswalkways/christchurchbotanicgardens/index.aspx |archivedate=19 October 2009 |df=dmy-all }} The Christchurch Botanic Gardens when on 9 July an [[English oak]] was planted to commemorate the solemnisation of marriage between [[Edward VII of the United Kingdom|Prince Albert]] and [[Alexandra of Denmark|Princess Alexandra]] of [[Denmark]]. The Gardens cover an area of 21 hectares,http://www1.ccc.govt.nz/webapps/parksaz/P44.asp Council website and lie adjacent to the loop of the Avon River next to Hagley Park. The Barbadoes Street Cemetery is a large green space in the north-east of the central city. It is the city’s oldest cemetery and opened in 1851. It is the final resting place of many of Christchurch’s early leading citizens. The cemetery itself is divided by Barbadoes Street separating the Anglican (Church of England) section, on the eastern side, from the Roman Catholic and Dissenters (others) section on the west.http://christchurchcitylibraries.com/Heritage/Cemeteries/Barbadoes/ Library information on the Barbadoes Street Cemetery The cemetery was initially envisaged to be much larger, but with the establishment of suburbs and villages with their own cemeteries, it became clear that less land was needed. The cemetery was subdivided in 1896 and Churchill Street was formed, with the eastern part of the original cemetery thus becoming a residential area.http://christchurchcitylibraries.com/Heritage/PlaceNames/ChristchurchStreetNames-C-E.pdf Information on Churchill Street == Transport == [[File:01 Christchurch 178 Brill car.jpg|thumb|right|A Christchurch tram]] Due to the grid pattern of the roads, the central city has a high number of traffic signals. Four pairs of one-way streets are located only a few hundred metres away from Cathedral Square, making it easy to drive through the city centre. The avenues in the north, east and south surrounding the central city are generally six-lane median divided. Fitzgerald and Bealey Avenues stand out due to the trees in those central medians. With about 30,000 car parks (both public and private), the central city has one of the highest ratios of car parking and employment of the [[OECD]] countries. As both driving and parking is relatively easy, Christchurch has a high car ownership rate. Cycling is reasonably popular in central Christchurch, with the second highest rate of commuter cycling in New Zealand (after Nelson). Free covered bike lock-ups are located in six City Council-run car parking buildings.http://www.ccc.govt.nz/cityleisure/gettingaround/cycling/cyclingguide.aspx Information on covered bicycle parking; accessed 12 January 2010 [[Public transport in Christchurch]] is mainly based on buses and supported by taxis. There is a functioning [http://www.tram.co.nz/ tram service] in Christchurch, but as a tourist attraction, its loop is restricted to a circuit of the central city and it does not fulfil a public transport function. The city council provided the current ''Bus Exchange'' between Lichfield and Cashel Streets in November 2000. A new ''Transport Interchange'' is planned for the block surrounded by Lichfield, Colombo, Tuam and Durham Streets, as the existing Bus Exchange is nearing capacity. Long distance buses depart mostly from Worcester Street near Cathedral Square. All local buses that go through the central city use the ''Bus Exchange''. It is envisaged that long distance and local services will all use the ''Transport Interchange''. In addition to normal bus services, the central city has a [[zero-fare]] [[hybrid vehicle|hybrid]] bus service, the ''Shuttle''. The [[Christchurch railway station (New Zealand)|railway station]] used to be located on the southern boundary of the central city on Moorhouse Avenue, but has been relocated to the suburb of [[Riccarton, New Zealand|Riccarton]]. == References == {{reflist|30em}} {{coord|-43.531|172.6365|region:NZ-CAN_type:city(4296)|display=title}} {{Christchurch City, New Zealand}} {{Christchurch earthquakes}} [[Category:Christchurch Central City| ]] [[Category:Populated places established in 1850]] [[Category:Geography of Christchurch]] [[Category:Central business districts in New Zealand]] [[Category:Economy of Christchurch]]

{{COI|date=July 2018}} [[File:Claire Dorland-Clauzel.jpg|thumb|Claire Dorland-Clauzel]]
'''Claire Dorland-Clauzel''' (born 15 November 1954 in [[Rennes]], [[French Fourth Republic|France]]) is a French businesswoman. From 2008 to 2018 she was the executive vice president of [[Michelin]]’s brands, [[sustainable development]], The [[Michelin Guide]] and external relations. She also was a member of the Group’s Executive Committee.
==Biography==
Claire Dorland-Clauzel studied [[khâgne]] at the [[lycée Henri-IV]] and obtained a master in History at [[La Sorbonne]].<ref name=bonnefee>{{Citation| last = Verdo| first = Yann | date = 14 Jun 2012 | title = Claire Dorland-Clauzel La bonne fée du Bibendum | journal = [[Les Échos (newspaper)|Les Échos]] | publication-place = Paris | language = French | url = http://www.lesechos.fr/14/06/2012/LesEchos/21205-053-ECH_claire-dorland-clauzel-la-bonne-fee-du-bibendum.htm | accessdate = 26 Jan 2016 | ref = harv}}</ref> She also obtained a doctorate in Geography at the Paris institute of Géographie and is an alumnus of the [[école nationale d’administration]] (class of 1988).<ref name=bonnefee/><ref name=bio>{{cite web|title=Claire Dorland-Clauzel - EXECUTIVE VICE PRESIDENT BRANDS AND EXTERNAL RELATIONS, MEMBER OF THE GROUP EXECUTIVE COMMITTEE|url=http://www.michelin.com/eng/michelin-group/governance/executive-committee-members-biographies/Claire-Dorland-Clauzel|website=michelin.com|publisher=MICHELIN|accessdate=23 June 2015}}</ref>
Claire Dorland-Clauzel started her career in the French public administration in 1988, at the department of treasury, in charge of foreign investments operating in France.<ref>{{cite web|title=Usinor Sacilor Claire DORLAND-CLAUZEL|url=http://www.lesechos.fr/05/01/1993/LesEchos/16300-077-ECH_usinor-sacilor-claire-dorland-clauzel.htm|website=lesechos.fr|publisher=LesEchos.fr|accessdate=23 June 2015}}</ref> In 1993, she took the lead of [[Christian Noyer]]'s cabinet when he was promoted head of the department of treasury<ref name=bonnefee /> and she also became deputy CFO to French steel-maker [[Usinor]].<ref name=prweek>{{cite web|last1=Washkuch|first1=Frank|title=Newsmaker: Claire Dorland Clauzel, Michelin|url=http://www.prweek.com/article/1277412/newsmaker-claire-dorland-clauzel-michelin|website=prweek.com|publisher=Haymarket Media Group Ltd.|accessdate=23 June 2015}}</ref> From 1995 to 1997, she became the chief of staff for the director of the treasury department,<ref name=prweek /> and joined [[Jean Arthuis]]’ cabinet as a technical advisor when he became [[Minister of the Economy, Finances and Industry (France)|minister of the economy]].<ref name=bio /> In 1997, she was the head of life and health insurance office of the treasury department.<ref name=prweek />
=== Axa === In 1998, Claire Dorland-Clauzel joined the insurance company [[AXA]] as the head of the audit and control department, and became a member of the executive committee. In 2000, she became AXA France’s head of support functions, and in 2003, she was appointed to head of communications and sustainable development. She also shifted from being a member of AXA France’ executive committee to being a member of the group’s committee.<ref name=bio />
=== Michelin === In 2008, Claire Dorland-Clauzel joined French pneumatic manufacturer [[Michelin]] as head of communications and member of Michelin's board of directors.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Parekh|first1=Rupal|title=Meet the Woman Behind the Michelin Man|url=http://adage.com/article/global-news/meet-woman-michelin-man/235309/|website=adage.com|publisher=Crain Communications|accessdate=23 June 2015}}</ref> In 2009, she managed Michelin’s first worldwide communications campaign.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Elliott|first1=Stuart|title=Will Consumers Tire of This Brand Character?|url=http://mediadecoder.blogs.nytimes.com/2009/10/06/will-consumers-tire-of-this-brand-character/?_r=1|website=mediadecoder.blogs.nytimes.com|publisher=The New York Times Company|accessdate=23 June 2015}}</ref> In June 2012, she was also given the supervision of public affairs, Michelin Lifestyle and Michelin Travel Partner, which made her the supervisor of the [[Michelin Guide]],<ref>{{cite web|last1=Klara|first1=Robert|title=The Most Powerful Woman in Restaurants Whom You've Never Met Claire Dorland-Clauzel is the marketing mind behind the Michelin Red Guide|url=http://www.adweek.com/news/advertising-branding/cmo-can-make-or-break-restaurant-one-night-160715|website=adweek.com|publisher=ADWEEK|accessdate=23 June 2015}}</ref> which she says is a crucial component of Michelin’s “[[Branded content|brand content]]” strategy to communicate on the quality of the products it caters to its customers.<ref>{{cite web|title=Le guide Michelin nous différencie des autres fabricants de pneumatiques|url=http://bfmbusiness.bfmtv.com/mediaplayer/video/le-guide-michelin-nous-differencie-des-autres-fabricants-de-pneumatiques-claire-dorland-clauzel-0302-402403.html|website=bfmbusiness.bfmtv.com|publisher=BFM TV|accessdate=23 June 2015}}</ref> In December 2014, she was appointed executive vice president of Michelin’s brands and external relations.<ref name=bio />
She oversaw the publication of five new [[Michelin guide]]s about cities in Asia and America between 2014 and 2017, including the first Michelin guide on China in 2016 with one guide dedicated to the city of [[Shanghai]].<ref>{{cite web |language=fr |url=http://www.huffingtonpost.fr/2016/09/21/guide-michelin-chine-etoiles-canton-8-shangai-restaurant_n_12114502.html |title=Le guide Michelin arrive en Chine... et donne deux étoiles au Canton 8, un restaurant à 6 euros |author= |date=21 Sep 2016 |website=huffingtonpost.fr |publisher= |access-date=27 Oct 2017 }}</ref>
From March 13, 2017 to 2018 she also was in charge of [[sustainable development]] and mobility for the Michelin group.<ref>{{cite web |language=fr |url=https://www.michelin.com/fre/groupe-michelin/gouvernance/dirigeants-biographies-michelin/Claire-Dorland-Clauzel |title=Claire Dorland-Clauzel |author= |date= |website=michelin.com |publisher=[[Michelin]] |access-date=27 Oct 2017 }}</ref> In this role, she supervises the organization of Movin'On, a global conference on sustainable mobility which picks up the baton from the [[Michelin Challenge Bibendum]] event.
The first edition<ref>{{cite web |language=en |url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/dougnewcomb/2017/07/08/michelin-stakes-a-claim-in-mobility-with-movinon-conference/#2652d3ca4f6a |title=Michelin Stakes A Claim In Mobility With Movin'On Conference |author=Geneviève Colonna d'Istria |date=8 Jul 2017 |website=forbes.com |publisher=[[Forbes]] |access-date=27 Oct 2017 }}</ref> took place in June 2017 in [[Montreal]], Canada. Michelin presented “Vision”, a concept wheel and tire that is airless, smart, uses 100% biodegradable bio-based materials and 3D printing.<ref>{{cite web |language=fr |url=https://www.usinenouvelle.com/article/michelin-presente-son-pneu-du-futur-au-movin-on-et-c-est-surprenant.N552628 |title=Michelin présente son pneu du futur au Movin'On… et c'est surprenant ! |author=Geneviève Colonna d'Istria |date=14 Jun 2017 |website=usinenouvelle.com |publisher=[[L'Usine nouvelle]] |access-date=27 Oct 2017 }}</ref>
In february 2018, she announced her departure from Michelin,<ref>{{cite web|language=fr|title=Claire Dorland Clauzel se confie sur son départ de Michelin, sa remplaçante est déjà connue|publisher=L'Usine Nouvelle|date=2018-02-27|issn=|url=https://www.usinenouvelle.com/article/claire-dorland-clauzel-se-confie-sur-son-depart-de-michelin-sa-remplacante-est-deja-connue.N659404|access-date=2018-04-02|}}</ref> to run a wine business, le « Château La Tuilière » in the Bordeaux wine-growing region.
==Awards== * Chevalier of the [[National Order of Merit (France)|National Order of Merit]] * Chevalier of the [[Legion of Honour]]
==References== {{Reflist}}

{{DEFAULTSORT:Dorland-Clauzel, Claire}} [[Category:1954 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:French businesspeople]] [[Category:Michelin people]] [[Category:École nationale d'administration alumni]] [[Category:Lycée Henri-IV alumni]] [[Category:Chevaliers of the Légion d'honneur]] [[Category:Knights of the National Order of Merit (France)]] [[Category:People from Rennes]]

'''Codentify''' is the name of a product serialization system developed and patented by [[Philip Morris International]] (PMI) for tobacco product authenticity verification and supply chain control. In the production process, each cigarette package is marked with a unique visible code (also called “Codentify”), that allows authenticating the code against a central server.<ref name=":2">{{cite web|url=http://www.pmi.com/eng/documents/Codentify_E_Brochure_English.pdf|title=Codentify E Brochure|last=|first=|date=|website=Pmi.com|publisher=|access-date=2017-03-04}}</ref><ref name=":0">{{Cite journal|last=Joossens|first=Luk|last2=Gilmore|first2=Anna B.|date=2013-03-12|title=The transnational tobacco companies’ strategy to promote Codentify, their inadequate tracking and tracing standard|url=http://tobaccocontrol.bmj.com/content/early/2013/03/11/tobaccocontrol-2012-050796|journal=Tobacco Control|language=en|pages=tobaccocontrol–2012-050796|doi=10.1136/tobaccocontrol-2012-050796|issn=1468-3318|pmc=3897562|pmid=23481904|volume=23}}</ref>
In November 2010, PMI licensed the system to its three main competitors, namely [[British American Tobacco]] (BAT), Imperial Tobacco Group (ITG), and [[Japan Tobacco International]] (JTI), and the four companies together formed the Digital Coding and Tracking Association (DCTA) which works to promote the system in order to replace governmental revenue stamps.<ref name=":1" /> Codentify is branded by its inventors as a “track & trace and product authentication technology”.<ref name=":2" />
== History == In July 2004, Phillip Morris International and the [[European Union]] had settled a 12 year long legal dispute concerning cigarette smuggling charges. PMI agreed to pay 1.25 Billion USD to the EU budget and its member states. In addition, PMI was legally obligated to mark its products with trackable serial codes.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/business/2004/jul/09/smoking.europeanunion|title=Philip Morris reaches $1.25bn EU agreement|last=Tran|first=Mark|date=2004-07-09|newspaper=The Guardian|language=en-GB|issn=0261-3077|access-date=2016-10-27}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://europa.eu/rapid/press-release_IP-04-882_en.htm|title=European Commission - PRESS RELEASES - Press release - European Commission and Philip Morris International sign 12-year Agreement to combat contraband and counterfeit cigarettes|website=europa.eu|access-date=2016-10-27}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.fctc.org/publications/bulletins/doc_view/451-legal-analysis-of-eu-agreements-with-multinational-tobacco-companies |title=Legal analysis of the agreements between the European Union, Member States, and multinational tobacco companies |author=Madeleine Heyward LL.M. (New York) |website=Fctc.org |accessdate=2017-03-04}}</ref> Agreements were subsequently signed with the other three major tobacco companies.
PMI's daughter company, Philip Morris Products S.A. created and patented the Codentify system in 2005.
In late 2010, PMI licensed Codentify to its main competitors BAT, JTI, and ITG free of charge.<ref name=":0" /><ref name=":1">{{Cite journal|title=Does the tobacco industry have a tracking and tracing system that governments can use?|url=http://www.fctc.org/images/stories/Codentify_final_220515.pdf|journal=WORLD NO TOBACCO DAY 2015|volume=}}</ref> The four companies, which together account for 71% of global cigarette sales (excluding China), agreed to use the PMI-developed system on all of their products to ensure “the adoption of a single industry standard, based on Codentify.”<ref>{{cite web|author1=Hill M|title=Digital Tax Verification (DTV) Codentify, The industry Standard, October 2010 and Philip Morris International, Codentify, Brochure, 2012|url=http://www.pmi.com/eng/documents/Codentify_E_Brochure_English.pdf|format=PDF|website=Pmi.com|accessdate=2017-03-04}}</ref> The Framework Convention on Tobacco Control (FCTC) immediately voiced concerns that “Codentify should never be used for tracking and tracing purposes as tracking and tracing provisions should be implemented under the strict control and management of governments.”<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.fctc.org/publications/bulletins/doc_view/493-bulletin-issue-113|title=Framework Convention Alliance Bulletin|last=|first=|date=|website=Fctc.org|access-date=2017-03-04}}</ref>
In 2011, the four companies formed the Digital Coding and Tracking Association (DCTA) to promote international standards and digital technologies to help governments fight smuggling, counterfeiting and tax evasion. The association was officially launched in 2013.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.marketwatch.com/story/association-launched-to-fight-illicit-trade-in-excisable-goods-2013-05-22|title=Association launched to fight illicit trade in excisable goods|newspaper=MarketWatch|access-date=2016-10-27}}</ref>
According to the DCTA, around 12% of the global cigarette market is illicit, depriving national governments of more than US$40 billion a year in lost tax revenues<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.aitcentral.com/content/tobacco-where-volume-counts-0|title=Tobacco: where volume counts|last=|first=|date=|website=AIT Central: fighting illicit trade|publisher=|access-date=}}</ref> and some say this is a serious underestimate.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ash.org.uk/files/documents/ASH_961.pdf|title=Illicit Tobacco: What is the Tobacco Industry Trying to Do?|last=|first=|date=|website=Ash.org.uk|publisher=|access-date=2017-03-04}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://opus.bath.ac.uk/38005/|title=Towards a greater understanding of the illicit tobacco trade in Europe: A review of the PMI funded ‘Project Star’ report|last=|first=|date=|website=Opus.bath.ac.uk|publisher=|access-date=}}</ref> The agreements between the EU and the four major tobacco companies aim to stem the illicit trade of cigarettes, but are seen by academics in the field as a wholly inadequate deterrent.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://tobaccocontrol.bmj.com/content/25/3/254 |title=Assessment of the European Union's illicit trade agreements with the four major Transnational Tobacco Companies | Tobacco Control |website=Tobaccocontrol.bmj.com |date= |accessdate=2017-03-04}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://ec.europa.eu/anti-fraud/investigations/eu-revenue/cigarette_smuggling_en |title=Tobacco smuggling - European Commission |website=Ec.europa.eu |date= |accessdate=2017-03-04}}</ref> The EU has since not renewed this deal after MEPs complained that it was ineffective and inappropriate that governments and tobacco companies have such a deal.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ft.com/cms/s/0/1724b620-42b9-11e6-b22f-79eb4891c97d.html#axzz4EpsiGmrl |title=EU to end anti-tobacco smuggling deal with Philip Morris |website=Ft.com |accessdate=2017-03-04}}</ref>
== Inexto == In June 2016 the DCTA announced that it transferred Codentify to Inexto, an affiliate of the French Group Impala.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.dcta-global.com/docs/DCTA_Press%20Release_1June2016.pdf |format=PDF |title=DCTA technology ownership transferred to Inexto, an affiliate of Impala Group |website=Dcta-global.com |accessdate=2017-03-04}}</ref> This was criticized by leading industry watchdogs such as the FCTC and academics such as Anna Gilmore, who is the director of the tobacco control research group at the University of Bath. She said that “Inexto could not be considered sufficiently independent from the tobacco industry". Martyn Day, Scottish National Party Member of Parliament, says while Codentify was sold "the new owner is merely a front company and that the system is still under the effective control of the tobacco firms".<ref>{{cite web|url=https://hansard.parliament.uk/Commons/2016-12-20/debates/FF51202E-34FA-48C7-B002-28DB6AF473AA/ChristmasAdjournment#contribution-2494C922-BC37-458E-A0E8-246FC3551B09|title=Christmas Adjournment - Hansard Online|website=hansard.parliament.uk|language=en|access-date=2017-02-28}}</ref> Other academics such as Luk Joossens, who is the advocacy officer of the Association of European Cancer Leagues, said the sale was “predictable” and that tobacco companies will now “pretend” that Codentify is no longer part of the tobacco industry.<ref>{{cite web|author=Saturday 4th Mar 2017 |url=https://euobserver.com/economic/133899 |title=Big Tobacco suspected of dodging EU anti-smuggling rules |website=Euobserver.com |date=2016-06-01 |accessdate=2017-03-04}}</ref> PMI have rebutted that “Inexto is fully independent from the tobacco industry."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://tobacco.cleartheair.org.hk/wp-content/uploads/2016/06/Pharmalutions-Joerss-Codentify-upd.pdf |format=PDF |title=Pharmalutions Pte Ltd |website=Tobacco.cleartheair.org.hk |accessdate=2017-03-04}}</ref>
A communiqué by Argentine lawyer Alejandro Sánchez Kalbermatten to the Security and Exchange Commission (SEC) explained the relationship between PMI, Inexto and Impala in a diagram.
== Technology == The Codentify system is based on a machine-created, unique, human-readable 12-digit alphanumeric code that is printed directly onto every individual product during the manufacturing process.<ref name=":3">{{cite web|url=http://www.iticnet.org/file/document/watch/3616|title=Digital Tax Verification|last=|first=|date=|website=Iticnet.org|publisher=|access-date=2017-03-04}}</ref> Factory level encryption keys are stored on a server and allows for the production of a pre-defined number of Codentify codes.<ref name=":1" />
The code created by the system is described as random, offering 34<sup>12</sup> possible combinations. A range of data can be encrypted into the code such as date and time of manufacture, the machine of manufacture, brand, variant, pack size, pack type, destination market, and price.<ref name=":3" />
This system presents limitations as it only allows for the verification of the code itself, not of the product the code is printed on and is potentially open to copying.<ref name=":0" /> A European Commission Assessment Report into Tracking and Tracing notes in section 5.1.2 that in addition to the Codentify code being easily copied, it also fails to link the cigarette packets to the master cases.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://ec.europa.eu/health/tobacco/do,cs/2015_tpd_tracking_tracing_frep_en.pdf|title=Analysis and Feasibility Assessment Regarding EU systems for Tracking and Tracing of Tobacco Products and for Security Features|last=|first=|date=|website=Ec.europa.eu|publisher=|access-date=2017-03-04}}</ref>
== Criticism == Codentify has been the subject of harsh criticism as a tobacco industry promoted system which is aimed at undermining public health efforts and not capable of curbing the illicit trade of cigarettes.<ref>{{Cite journal|title=Condentify: an industry attempt to control illicit trade|url=https://www.stopcorporateabuse.org/sites/default/files/resources/codentify-flyer.pdf|journal=Corporate Accountability International|volume=}}</ref> This criticism has come from academics and pro-health groups<ref name=":0" /> as well as government agencies, including the [[World Health Organization|WHO]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.who.int/fctc/mediacentre/news/2016/remarks-head-fctc-high-level-conference-brussels/en/|title=Dr Vera Luiza da Costa e Silva, head of the Convention Secretariat, sends her remarks to the High Level Conference: Combating tobacco industry tactics: state of play and a way forward, European Parliament, Brussels, 2 March 2016|website=World Health Organization|language=en-GB|access-date=2016-10-27}}</ref>
The WHO [[WHO Framework Convention on Tobacco Control|FCTC Protocol]] on the Elimination of the Illicit Trade in Tobacco products states in article 8, section 12 that tobacco tracking and regulation “shall not be performed by or delegated to the tobacco industry”.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://apps.who.int/iris/bitstream/10665/80873/1/9789241505246_eng.pdf |format=PDF |title=Protocol to Eliminate Illicit Trade in Tobacco Products |website=Apps.who.int |accessdate=2017-03-04}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://whyitisbad.wordpress.com/2016/02/29/world-health-organization-is-the-solution-for-codentify/|title=World Health Organization is the Solution for Codentify|last=whyitsbad|date=2016-02-29|website=Why It's Bad|access-date=2016-10-27}}</ref>
Critics of the tobacco industry say Codentify is simply not good enough, “because it focuses too much on production and does not store product codes or track them.”<ref name=":0" /><ref>{{Cite news|url=http://uk.reuters.com/article/us-tobacco-tracking-insight-idUSKBN0ET0I720140618|title=Big Tobacco squares up as EU rules aim to track every cigarette|last=Geller|first=Martinne|newspaper=Reuters UK|language=en-GB|access-date=2016-10-27}}</ref>
Heavy criticism has also been launched at the factory-level keys the system uses to provide unique verification codes for the product. Since these secret keys are stored on company and government servers, abuse of privileges on this level would allow criminals to generate additional codes, which would appear to be genuine to the system.<ref name=":0" /><ref name=":4">{{cite web|url=http://www.tobaccofact.org/blog/major-flaws-discovered-in-the-codentify-track-and-trace-system|title=Major Flaws Discovered in the Codentify Track and Trace System|website=Tobacco Industry facts|access-date=2016-10-27}}</ref><ref>{{Citation|last=Why It Is Bad - Tobacco Track and Trace|title=Codentify - Interview with a Tobacco Industry Insider|date=2015-05-28|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=XQ7gZ_D_WMM|accessdate=2016-10-27}}</ref>
The decentralized nature of the system also allows for a variety of other counterfeiting efforts critics say, such as “code recycling”, using codes of products rejected in quality control, “code cloning”, printing the same code on multiple products, and “code migration”, reprinting codes used in one country elsewhere, allowing the reuse of genuine codes multiple times.<ref name=":4" />
Additionally, [[Action on Smoking and Health]] (ASH) described the system as a black box created by the tobacco industry that uses unsecured equipment that is vulnerable to code recycling.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.fctc.org/images/stories/Codentify_final_220515.pdf |format=PDF |title=Does the tobacco industry have a tracking and tracing system that governments can use? |website=Fctc.org |accessdate=2017-03-04}}</ref>
==References== {{Reflist|30em}}
[[Category:Tobacco industry]]

revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=March 2018}} {{Use British English|date=March 2018}} '''David Ramsay Hay''' {{Post-nominals|post-noms=[[Fellow of the Royal Society of Edinburgh|FRSE]]}} (March 1798, Edinburgh – 10 September 1866) was a Scottish artist, [[interior decorator]] and [[colour theorist]].
==Life== [[File:Abbotsford04.jpg|thumb|Entrance Hall at Abbotsford, decorated by David Ramsay Hay, 1824]] [[File:The grave of David Ramsay Hay, Warriston Cemetery, Edinburgh.jpg|thumb|The grave of David Ramsay Hay, Warriston Cemetery, Edinburgh]] David Ramsay Hay was the son of Rebekah or Rebecca Carmichael, a published poet and friend of [[Robert Burns]].<ref>Lonsdale, Roger H., ed., ''Eighteenth Century Women Poets: an Anthology'', OUP (1990) 445.</ref> They lived at the foot of Monteith's Close off the [[Royal Mile]] in [[Edinburgh]].<ref>Edinburgh and Leith Post Office Directory 1798</ref> After her husband died prematurely and penniless, David was educated at the expense of her brother, David Ramsay, a banker and owner of the ''Edinburgh Evening Courant''<ref>http://oxfordindex.oup.com/view/10.1093/oi/authority.20110810105045960</ref> then apprenticed as a reading-boy in Ramsay's printing office in [[Edinburgh]]. Instead though (around 1813), Hay moved to join Gavin Beugo (son of [[John Beugo]])<ref>http://archiveshub.ac.uk/data/gb237-coll-329</ref> a decorative artist, based on West Register Street in [[New Town, Edinburgh|Edinburgh's New Town]].<ref>Edinburgh and Leith Post Office Directory 1812</ref> His fellow-apprentice was his friend, the topographical artist [[David Roberts (painter)|David Roberts]]. In April 1820 he commenced work at [[Abbotsford House|Abbotsford]] for [[Walter Scott]].<ref>Hay, ''Harmonious Colouring'', 6th edition (1847), 182.</ref> In 1850 he decorated [[Holyroodhouse]] for [[Queen Victoria]]. In the 1920s, [[Mary of Teck|Queen Mary]] had these decorative schemes painted over, but watercolours commissioned by Victoria in 1863 give some idea of their appearance.<ref>Morton, Theresa-May, ''Royal Residences of the Victorian Era'', The Royal Collection (1991), 53-59</ref>
Hay was an advocate of imitative finishes such as graining and marbling, and textured paints to imitate brocade fabrics.<ref>Bristow, Ian C., ''Interior House Painting Colours & Technology, 1615-1840'', Yale (1996), 141.</ref> From 1828, he developed his theory of colour harmony over six successive editions of his book, ''The Laws of Harmonious Colouring Adapted to Interior Decorations''.<ref>Bristow, Ian C., ''Architectural Colour in British Interiors, 1615-1840'', Yale (1996), 191</ref> Hay wrote about his experience decorating Abbotsford for Walter Scott in the sixth edition of his ''Harmonious Colouring.''<ref>''Harmonious Colouring'', 6th edition (1847), pp.181-97, see external links.</ref>
In his final years he had exclusive premises at 90 George Street in the centre of Edinburgh's New Town.<ref>Edinburgh and Leith Post Office Directory 1866-67</ref>
He died in [[Edinburgh]] on 10 September 1866.<ref>http://archiveshub.ac.uk/data/gb237-coll-329</ref> He is buried in [[Warriston Cemetery]] in the north of the city. The substantial tombstone stands to the south-west of the sealed eastern entrance. The monument is vandalised and the original bronze bas-relief sculpture of his profile has been stolen.
==Publications== see<ref>https://en.wikisource.org/wiki/Hay,_David_Ramsay_(DNB00)</ref> *''The Laws of Harmonious Colouring in House Painting'' (1828) *''The Natural Principles and Analogy of the Harmony of Form'' (1842) *''Proportion: or the Geometric Principle of Beauty Analysed'' (1843) *''First Principles of Symmetrical Beauty'' (1846) *''The Science of Beauty'' (1856)<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://archive.org/details/scienceofbeautya00hayd_0|title=The Science of Beauty|last=Hay|first=David|date=1856|publisher=William Blackwood & Sons|access-date=2018-08-06}}</ref>
==References== {{Reflist|30em}}
==External links== * [http://www.npg.org.uk/research/conservation/directory-of-british-framemakers/h.php National Portrait Gallery page with biography of Hay] * [https://books.google.com/books?id=aVQCAAAAQAAJ&source=gbs_navlinks_s Carmichael, Rebekah, ''Poems by Miss Carmichael'', Edinburgh (1790)] (list of subscribers names of interest) * [https://books.google.com/books?id=8g0wAAAAYAAJ&source=gbs_navlinks_s Hay, David Ramsay, ''The Laws of Harmonious Colouring Adapted to Interior Decorations'', 3rd edition (1836)] * [http://conservation.historic-scotland.gov.uk/publication-detail?pubid=8660 Hay, David Ramsay, ''The Laws of Harmonious Colouring Adapted to Interior Decorations'', 6th edition (1847)] digitised by [[Historic Scotland]] * [https://books.google.com/books?id=iQUtAAAAYAAJ&source=gbs_navlinks_s Hay, David Ramsay, ''Proportion or, The Laws of Beauty Analysed'', Blackwood (1843)] * [https://books.google.com/books?id=SystAAAAYAAJ&source=gbs_navlinks_s Hay, David Ramsay, ''The Principles of Beauty in Colouring Systematized'', Blackwood (1845)] * [https://books.google.com/books?id=B0gEAAAAYAAJ&source=gbs_navlinks_s Hay, David Ramsay, ''First Principles of Symmetrical Beauty'', Blackwood (1846)] * [https://books.google.com/books?id=ECsDAAAAQAAJ&source=gbs_navlinks_s Hay, David Ramsay, ''The Natural Principle of Beauty, as developed in the Human Figure'', Blackwood (1852)] * [https://books.google.com/books?id=1BBNAAAAMAAJ&source=gbs_navlinks_s Hay, David Ramsay, ''The Harmonic Law of Nature Applied to Architectural Design'', Blackwood (1855)] * [https://books.google.com/books?id=04ufAAAAMAAJ&source=gbs_navlinks_s Hay, David Ramsay, ''The Science of Beauty: as developed in Applied Art and Nature'', Blackwood (1856)]
{{Authority control}}
